ulnar collateral ligament.definition: intrinsic ligament on the medial side of the elbow joint; spans from the medial epicondyle of the humerus to the medial ulna

uniaxial joint.definition: type of diarthrosis; joint that allows for motion within only one plane (one axis)

zygapophysial joints.definition: facet joints; plane joints between the superior and inferior articular processes of adjacent vertebrae that provide for only limited motions between the vertebrae

acetylcholine (ACh).definition: neurotransmitter that binds at a motor end-plate to trigger depolarization

actin.definition: protein that makes up most of the thin myofilaments in a sarcomere muscle fiber

action potential.definition: change in voltage of a cell membrane in response to a stimulus that results in transmission of an electrical signal; unique to neurons and muscle fibers

aerobic respiration.definition: production of ATP in the presence of oxygen

aponeurosis.definition: broad, tendon-like sheet of connective tissue that attaches a skeletal muscle to another skeletal muscle or to a bone

ATPase.definition: enzyme that hydrolyzes ATP to ADP

atrophy.definition: loss of structural proteins from muscle fibers

autorhythmicity.definition: heartâs ability to control its own contractions

calmodulin.definition: regulatory protein that facilitates contraction in smooth muscles

cardiac muscle.definition: striated muscle found in the heart; joined to one another at intercalated discs and under the regulation of pacemaker cells, which contract as one unit to pump blood through the circulatory system. Cardiac muscle is under involuntary control.

concentric contraction.definition: muscle contraction that shortens the muscle to move a load

contraction phase.definition: twitch contraction phase when tension increases

creatine phosphate.definition: phosphagen used to store energy from ATP and transfer it to muscle

dense body.definition: sarcoplasmic structure that attaches to the sarcolemma and shortens the muscle as thin filaments slide past thick filaments

depolarize.definition: to reduce the voltage difference between the inside and outside of a cellâs plasma membrane (the sarcolemma for a muscle fiber), making the inside less negative than at rest

desmosome.definition: cell structure that anchors the ends of cardiac muscle fibers to allow contraction to occur

eccentric contraction.definition: muscle contraction that lengthens the muscle as the tension is diminished

endomysium.definition: loose, and well-hydrated connective tissue covering each muscle fiber in a skeletal muscle

epimysium.definition: outer layer of connective tissue around a skeletal muscle

excitation-contraction coupling.definition: sequence of events from motor neuron signaling to a skeletal muscle fiber to contraction of the fiberâs sarcomeres

fascicle.definition: bundle of muscle fibers within a skeletal muscle

fast glycolytic (FG).definition: muscle fiber that primarily uses anaerobic glycolysis

fast oxidative (FO).definition: intermediate muscle fiber that is between slow oxidative and fast glycolytic fibers

fibrosis.definition: replacement of muscle fibers by scar tissue

glycolysis.definition: anaerobic breakdown of glucose to ATP

hyperplasia.definition: process in which one cell splits to produce new cells

hypertrophy.definition: addition of structural proteins to muscle fibers

hypotonia.definition: abnormally low muscle tone caused by the absence of low-level contractions

intercalated disc.definition: part of the sarcolemma that connects cardiac tissue, and contains gap junctions and desmosomes

isometric contraction.definition: muscle contraction that occurs with no change in muscle length

isotonic contraction.definition: muscle contraction that involves changes in muscle length

latch-bridges.definition: subset of a cross-bridge in which actin and myosin remain locked together

latent period.definition: the time when a twitch does not produce contraction

motor end-plate.definition: sarcolemma of muscle fiber at the neuromuscular junction, with receptors for the neurotransmitter acetylcholine

motor unit.definition: motor neuron and the group of muscle fibers it innervates

muscle tension.definition: force generated by the contraction of the muscle; tension generated during isotonic contractions and isometric contractions

muscle tone.definition: low levels of muscle contraction that occur when a muscle is not producing movement

myofibril.definition: long, cylindrical organelle that runs parallel within the muscle fiber and contains the sarcomeres

myogram.definition: instrument used to measure twitch tension

myosin.definition: protein that makes up most of the thick cylindrical myofilament within a sarcomere muscle fiber

neuromuscular junction (NMJ).definition: synapse between the axon terminal of a motor neuron and the section of the membrane of a muscle fiber with receptors for the acetylcholine released by the terminal

neurotransmitter.definition: signaling chemical released by nerve terminals that bind to and activate receptors on target cells

oxygen debt.definition: amount of oxygen needed to compensate for ATP produced without oxygen during muscle contraction

pacesetter cell.definition: cell that triggers action potentials in smooth muscle

pericyte.definition: stem cell that regenerates smooth muscle cells

perimysium.definition: connective tissue that bundles skeletal muscle fibers into fascicles within a skeletal muscle

power stroke.definition: action of myosin pulling actin inward (toward the M line)

pyruvic acid.definition: product of glycolysis that can be used in aerobic respiration or converted to lactic acid

recruitment.definition: increase in the number of motor units involved in contraction

relaxation phase.definition: period after twitch contraction when tension decreases

sarcolemma.definition: plasma membrane of a skeletal muscle fiber

sarcomere.definition: longitudinally, repeating functional unit of skeletal muscle, with all of the contractile and associated proteins involved in contraction

sarcoplasmic reticulum (SR).definition: specialized smooth endoplasmic reticulum, which stores, releases, and retrieves Ca++

satellite cell.definition: stem cell that helps to repair muscle cells

skeletal muscle.definition: striated, multinucleated muscle that requires signaling from the nervous system to trigger contraction; most skeletal muscles are referred to as voluntary muscles that move bones and produce movement

slow oxidative (SO).definition: muscle fiber that primarily uses aerobic respiration

smooth muscle.definition: nonstriated, mononucleated muscle in the skin that is associated with hair follicles; assists in moving materials in the walls of internal organs, blood vessels, and internal passageways

stress-relaxation response.definition: relaxation of smooth muscle tissue after being stretched

synaptic cleft.definition: space between a nerve (axon) terminal and a motor end-plate

T-tubule.definition: projection of the sarcolemma into the interior of the cell

thick filament.definition: the thick myosin strands and their multiple heads projecting from the center of the sarcomere toward, but not all to way to, the Z-discs

thin filament.definition: thin strands of actin and its troponin-tropomyosin complex projecting from the Z-discs toward the center of the sarcomere

triad.definition: the grouping of one T-tubule and two terminal cisternae

tropomyosin.definition: regulatory protein that covers myosin-binding sites to prevent actin from binding to myosin

troponin.definition: regulatory protein that binds to actin, tropomyosin, and calcium

twitch.definition: single contraction produced by one action potential

varicosity.definition: enlargement of neurons that release neurotransmitters into synaptic clefts

visceral muscle.definition: smooth muscle found in the walls of visceral organs

voltage-gated sodium channels.definition: membrane proteins that open sodium channels in response to a sufficient voltage change, and initiate and transmit the action potential as Na+enters through the channel

wave summation.definition: addition of successive neural stimuli to produce greater contraction

abduct.definition: move away from midline in the sagittal plane

abductor.definition: moves the bone away from the midline

abductor digiti minimi.definition: muscle that abducts the little finger

abductor pollicis longus.definition: muscle that inserts into the first metacarpal

adductor.definition: moves the bone toward the midline

adductor brevis.definition: muscle that adducts and medially rotates the thigh

adductor longus.definition: muscle that adducts, medially rotates, and flexes the thigh

adductor magnus.definition: muscle with an anterior fascicle that adducts, medially rotates and flexes the thigh, and a posterior fascicle that assists in thigh extension

agonist.definition: (also, prime mover) muscle whose contraction is responsible for producing a particular motion

anal triangle.definition: posterior triangle of the perineum that includes the anus

anconeus.definition: small muscle on the lateral posterior elbow that extends the forearm

antagonist.definition: muscle that opposes the action of an agonist

anterior compartment of the arm.definition: (anterior flexor compartment of the arm) the biceps brachii, brachialis, brachioradialis, and their associated blood vessels and nerves

anterior compartment of the forearm.definition: (anterior flexor compartment of the forearm) deep and superficial muscles that originate on the humerus and insert into the hand

anterior compartment of the leg.definition: region that includes muscles that dorsiflex the foot

anterior compartment of the thigh.definition: region that includes muscles that flex the thigh and extend the leg

anterior scalene.definition: a muscle anterior to the middle scalene

belly.definition: bulky central body of a muscle

biceps brachii.definition: two-headed muscle that crosses the shoulder and elbow joints to flex the forearm while assisting in supinating it and flexing the arm at the shoulder

bipennate.definition: pennate muscle that has fascicles that are located on both sides of the tendon

brachialis.definition: muscle deep to the biceps brachii that provides power in flexing the forearm.

brachioradialis.definition: muscle that can flex the forearm quickly or help lift a load slowly

calcaneal tendon.definition: (also, Achilles tendon) strong tendon that inserts into the calcaneal bone of the ankle

caval opening.definition: opening in the diaphragm that allows the inferior vena cava to pass through; foramen for the vena cava

circular.definition: (also, sphincter) fascicles that are concentrically arranged around an opening

convergent.definition: fascicles that extend over a broad area and converge on a common attachment site

coracobrachialis.definition: muscle that flexes and adducts the arm

deep anterior compartment.definition: flexor pollicis longus, flexor digitorum profundus, and their associated blood vessels and nerves

deep posterior compartment of the forear.definition: (deep posterior extensor compartment of the forearm) the abductor pollicis longus, extensor pollicis brevis, extensor pollicis longus, extensor indicis, and their associated blood vessels and nerves

deltoid.definition: shoulder muscle that abducts the arm as well as flexes and medially rotates it, and extends and laterally rotates it

diaphragm.definition: skeletal muscle that separates the thoracic and abdominal cavities and is dome-shaped at rest

digastric.definition: muscle that has anterior and posterior bellies and elevates the hyoid bone and larynx when one swallows; it also depresses the mandible

dorsal group.definition: region that includes the extensor digitorum brevis

dorsal interossei.definition: muscles that abduct and flex the three middle fingers at the metacarpophalangeal joints and extend them at the interphalangeal joints

epicranial aponeurosis.definition: (also, galea aponeurosis) flat broad tendon that connects the frontalis and occipitalis

erector spinae group.definition: large muscle mass of the back; primary extensor of the vertebral column

extensor.definition: muscle that increases the angle at the joint

extensor carpi radialis brevis.definition: muscle that extends and abducts the hand at the wrist

extensor carpi ulnaris.definition: muscle that extends and adducts the hand

extensor digiti minimi.definition: muscle that extends the little finger

extensor digitorum.definition: muscle that extends the hand at the wrist and the phalanges

extensor digitorum longus.definition: muscle that is lateral to the tibialis anterior

extensor hallucis longus.definition: muscle that is partly deep to the tibialis anterior and extensor digitorum longus

extensor indicis.definition: muscle that inserts onto the tendon of the extensor digitorum of the index finger

extensor pollicis brevis.definition: muscle that inserts onto the base of the proximal phalanx of the thumb

extensor pollicis longus.definition: muscle that inserts onto the base of the distal phalanx of the thumb

extensor radialis longus.definition: muscle that extends and abducts the hand at the wrist

extensor retinaculum.definition: band of connective tissue that extends over the dorsal surface of the hand

external intercostal.definition: superficial intercostal muscles that raise the rib cage

external oblique.definition: superficial abdominal muscle with fascicles that extend inferiorly and medially

extrinsic eye muscles.definition: originate outside the eye and insert onto the outer surface of the white of the eye, and create eyeball movement

extrinsic muscles of the hand.definition: muscles that move the wrists, hands, and fingers and originate on the arm

fascicle.definition: muscle fibers bundled by perimysium into a unit

femoral triangle.definition: region formed at the junction between the hip and the leg and includes the pectineus, femoral nerve, femoral artery, femoral vein, and deep inguinal lymph nodes

fibularis brevis.definition: (also, peroneus brevis) muscle that plantar flexes the foot at the ankle and everts it at the intertarsal joints

fibularis longus.definition: (also, peroneus longus) muscle that plantar flexes the foot at the ankle and everts it at the intertarsal joints

fibularis tertius.definition: small muscle that is associated with the extensor digitorum longus

fixator.definition: synergist that assists an agonist by preventing or reducing movement at another joint, thereby stabilizing the origin of the agonist

flexion.definition: movement that decreases the angle of a joint

flexor.definition: muscle that decreases the angle at the joint

flexor carpi radialis.definition: muscle that flexes and abducts the hand at the wrist

flexor carpi ulnaris.definition: muscle that flexes and adducts the hand at the wrist

flexor digiti minimi brevis.definition: muscle that flexes the little finger

flexor digitorum longus.definition: muscle that flexes the four small toes

flexor digitorum profundus.definition: muscle that flexes the phalanges of the fingers and the hand at the wrist

flexor digitorum superficialis.definition: muscle that flexes the hand and the digits

flexor hallucis longus.definition: muscle that flexes the big toe

flexor pollicis longus.definition: muscle that flexes the distal phalanx of the thumb

flexor retinaculum.definition: band of connective tissue that extends over the palmar surface of the hand

frontalis.definition: front part of the occipitofrontalis muscle

fusiform.definition: muscle that has fascicles that are spindle-shaped to create large bellies

gastrocnemius.definition: most superficial muscle of the calf

genioglossus.definition: muscle that originates on the mandible and allows the tongue to move downward and forward

geniohyoid.definition: muscle that depresses the mandible, and raises and pulls the hyoid bone anteriorly

gluteal group.definition: muscle group that extends, flexes, rotates, adducts, and abducts the femur

gluteus maximus.definition: largest of the gluteus muscles that extends the femur

gluteus medius.definition: muscle deep to the gluteus maximus that abducts the femur at the hip

gluteus minimus.definition: smallest of the gluteal muscles and deep to the gluteus medius

gracilis.definition: muscle that adducts the thigh and flexes the leg at the knee

hamstring group.definition: three long muscles on the back of the leg

hyoglossus.definition: muscle that originates on the hyoid bone to move the tongue downward and flatten it

hypothenar.definition: group of muscles on the medial aspect of the palm

hypothenar eminence.definition: rounded contour of muscle at the base of the little finger

iliacus.definition: muscle that, along with the psoas major, makes up the iliopsoas

iliococcygeus.definition: muscle that makes up the levator ani along with the pubococcygeus

iliocostalis cervicis.definition: muscle of the iliocostalis group associated with the cervical region

iliocostalis group.definition: laterally placed muscles of the erector spinae

iliocostalis lumborum.definition: muscle of the iliocostalis group associated with the lumbar region

iliocostalis thoracis.definition: muscle of the iliocostalis group associated with the thoracic region

iliopsoas group.definition: muscle group consisting of iliacus and psoas major muscles, that flexes the thigh at the hip, rotates it laterally, and flexes the trunk of the body onto the hip

iliotibial tract.definition: muscle that inserts onto the tibia; made up of the gluteus maximus and connective tissues of the tensor fasciae latae

inferior gemellus.definition: muscle deep to the gluteus maximus on the lateral surface of the thigh that laterally rotates the femur at the hip

infrahyoid muscles.definition: anterior neck muscles that are attached to, and inferior to the hyoid bone

infraspinatus.definition: muscle that laterally rotates the arm

innermost intercostal.definition: the deepest intercostal muscles that draw the ribs together

insertion.definition: end of a skeletal muscle that is attached to the structure (usually a bone) that is moved when the muscle contracts

intercostal muscles.definition: muscles that span the spaces between the ribs

internal intercostal.definition: muscles the intermediate intercostal muscles that draw the ribs together

internal oblique.definition: flat, intermediate abdominal muscle with fascicles that run perpendicular to those of the external oblique

intrinsic muscles of the hand.definition: muscles that move the wrists, hands, and fingers and originate in the palm

ischiococcygeus.definition: muscle that assists the levator ani and pulls the coccyx anteriorly

lateral compartment of the leg.definition: region that includes the fibularis (peroneus) longus and the fibularis (peroneus) brevis and their associated blood vessels and nerves

lateral pterygoid.definition: muscle that moves the mandible from side to side

latissimus dorsi.definition: broad, triangular axial muscle located on the inferior part of the back

levator ani.definition: pelvic muscle that resists intra-abdominal pressure and supports the pelvic viscera

linea alba.definition: white, fibrous band that runs along the midline of the trunk

longissimus capitis.definition: muscle of the longissimus group associated with the head region

longissimus cervicis.definition: muscle of the longissimus group associated with the cervical region

longissimus group.definition: intermediately placed muscles of the erector spinae

longissimus thoracis.definition: muscle of the longissimus group associated with the thoracic region

lumbrical.definition: muscle that flexes each finger at the metacarpophalangeal joints and extend each finger at the interphalangeal joints

masseter.definition: main muscle for chewing that elevates the mandible to close the mouth

medial compartment of the thigh.definition: a region that includes the adductor longus, adductor brevis, adductor magnus, pectineus, gracilis, and their associated blood vessels and nerves

medial pterygoid.definition: muscle that moves the mandible from side to side

middle scalene.definition: longest scalene muscle, located between the anterior and posterior scalenes

multifidus.definition: muscle of the lumbar region that helps extend and laterally flex the vertebral column

multipennate.definition: pennate muscle that has a tendon branching within it

mylohyoid.definition: muscle that lifts the hyoid bone and helps press the tongue to the top of the mouth

obturator externus.definition: muscle deep to the gluteus maximus on the lateral surface of the thigh that laterally rotates the femur at the hip

obturator internus.definition: muscle deep to the gluteus maximus on the lateral surface of the thigh that laterally rotates the femur at the hip

occipitalis.definition: posterior part of the occipitofrontalis muscle

occipitofrontalis.definition: muscle that makes up the scalp with a frontal belly and an occipital belly

omohyoid.definition: muscle that has superior and inferior bellies and depresses the hyoid bone

opponens digiti minimi.definition: muscle that brings the little finger across the palm to meet the thumb

opponens pollicis.definition: muscle that moves the thumb across the palm to meet another finger

orbicularis oculi.definition: circular muscle that closes the eye

orbicularis oris.definition: circular muscle that moves the lips

origin.definition: end of a skeletal muscle that is attached to another structure (usually a bone) in a fixed position

palatoglossus.definition: muscle that originates on the soft palate to elevate the back of the tongue

palmar interossei.definition: muscles that abduct and flex each finger at the metacarpophalangeal joints and extend each finger at the interphalangeal joints

palmaris longus.definition: muscle that provides weak flexion of the hand at the wrist

parallel.definition: fascicles that extend in the same direction as the long axis of the muscle

patellar ligament.definition: extension of the quadriceps tendon below the patella

pectineus.definition: muscle that abducts and flexes the femur at the hip

pectoral girdle.definition: shoulder girdle, made up of the clavicle and scapula

pectoralis major.definition: thick, fan-shaped axial muscle that covers much of the superior thorax

pectoralis minor.definition: muscle that moves the scapula and assists in inhalation

pelvic diaphragm.definition: muscular sheet that comprises the levator ani and the ischiococcygeus

pelvic girdle.definition: hips, a foundation for the lower limb

pennate.definition: fascicles that are arranged differently based on their angles to the tendon

perineum.definition: diamond-shaped region between the pubic symphysis, coccyx, and ischial tuberosities

piriformis.definition: muscle deep to the gluteus maximus on the lateral surface of the thigh that laterally rotates the femur at the hip

plantar aponeurosis.definition: muscle that supports the longitudinal arch of the foot

plantar group.definition: four-layered group of intrinsic foot muscles

plantaris.definition: muscle that runs obliquely between the gastrocnemius and the soleus

popliteal fossa.definition: diamond-shaped space at the back of the knee

popliteus.definition: muscle that flexes the leg at the knee and creates the floor of the popliteal fossa

posterior compartment of the leg.definition: region that includes the superficial gastrocnemius, soleus, and plantaris, and the deep popliteus, flexor digitorum longus, flexor hallucis longus, and tibialis posterior

posterior compartment of the thigh.definition: region that includes muscles that flex the leg and extend the thigh

posterior scalene.definition: smallest scalene muscle, located posterior to the middle scalene

prime mover.definition: (also, agonist) principle muscle involved in an action

pronator quadratus.definition: pronator that originates on the ulna and inserts on the radius

pronator teres.definition: pronator that originates on the humerus and inserts on the radius

psoas major.definition: muscle that, along with the iliacus, makes up the iliopsoas

pubococcygeus.definition: muscle that makes up the levator ani along with the iliococcygeus

quadratus femoris.definition: muscle deep to the gluteus maximus on the lateral surface of the thigh that laterally rotates the femur at the hip

quadratus lumborum.definition: posterior part of the abdominal wall that helps with posture and stabilization of the body

quadriceps femoris group.definition: four muscles, that extend and stabilize the knee

quadriceps tendon.definition: (also, patellar tendon) tendon common to all four quadriceps muscles, inserts into the patella

rectus abdominis.definition: long, linear muscle that extends along the middle of the trunk

rectus femoris.definition: quadricep muscle on the anterior aspect of the thigh

rectus sheaths.definition: tissue that makes up the linea alba

retinacula.definition: fibrous bands that sheath the tendons at the wrist

rhomboid major.definition: muscle that attaches the vertebral border of the scapula to the spinous process of the thoracic vertebrae

rhomboid minor.definition: muscle that attaches the vertebral border of the scapula to the spinous process of the thoracic vertebrae

rotator cuff.definition: (also, musculotendinous cuff) the circle of tendons around the shoulder joint

sartorius.definition: band-like muscle that flexes, abducts, and laterally rotates the leg at the hip

scalene muscles.definition: flex, laterally flex, and rotate the head; contribute to deep inhalation

segmental muscle group.definition: interspinales and intertransversarii muscles that bring together the spinous and transverse processes of each consecutive vertebra

semispinalis capitis.definition: transversospinales muscle associated with the head region

semispinalis cervicis.definition: transversospinales muscle associated with the cervical region

semispinalis thoracis.definition: transversospinales muscle associated with the thoracic region

serratus anterior.definition: large and flat muscle that originates on the ribs and inserts onto the scapula

soleus.definition: wide, flat muscle deep to the gastrocnemius

spinalis capitis.definition: muscle of the spinalis group associated with the head region

spinalis cervicis.definition: muscle of the spinalis group associated with the cervical region

spinalis group.definition: medially placed muscles of the erector spinae

spinalis thoracis.definition: muscle of the spinalis group associated with the thoracic region

splenius.definition: posterior neck muscles; includes the splenius capitis and splenius cervicis

splenius capitis.definition: neck muscle that inserts into the head region

splenius cervicis.definition: neck muscle that inserts into the cervical region

sternocleidomastoid.definition: major muscle that laterally flexes and rotates the head

sternohyoid.definition: muscle that depresses the hyoid bone

sternothyroid.definition: muscle that depresses the larynxâs thyroid cartilage

styloglossus.definition: muscle that originates on the styloid bone, and allows upward and backward motion of the tongue

stylohyoid.definition: muscle that elevates the hyoid bone posteriorly

subclavius.definition: muscle that stabilizes the clavicle during movement

subscapularis.definition: muscle that originates on the anterior scapula and medially rotates the arm

superficial anterior compartment of the.definition: flexor carpi radialis, palmaris longus, flexor carpi ulnaris, flexor digitorum superficialis, and their associated blood vessels and nerves

superficial posterior compartment of the.definition: extensor radialis longus, extensor carpi radialis brevis, extensor digitorum, extensor digiti minimi, extensor carpi ulnaris, and their associated blood vessels and nerves

superior gemellus.definition: muscle deep to the gluteus maximus on the lateral surface of the thigh that laterally rotates the femur at the hip

supinator.definition: muscle that moves the palm and forearm anteriorly

suprahyoid muscles.definition: neck muscles that are superior to the hyoid bone

synergist.definition: muscle whose contraction helps a prime mover in an action

tendinous intersections.definition: three transverse bands of collagen fibers that divide the rectus abdominis into segments

tensor fascia lata.definition: muscle that flexes and abducts the thigh

teres major.definition: muscle that extends the arm and assists in adduction and medial rotation of it

teres minor.definition: muscle that laterally rotates and extends the arm

thenar.definition: group of muscles on the lateral aspect of the palm

thenar eminence.definition: rounded contour of muscle at the base of the thumb

thyrohyoid.definition: muscle that depresses the hyoid bone and elevates the larynxâs thyroid cartilage

tibialis anterior.definition: muscle located on the lateral surface of the tibia

tibialis posterior.definition: muscle that plantar flexes and inverts the foot

transversospinales.definition: muscles that originate at the transverse processes and insert at the spinous processes of the vertebrae

transversus abdominis.definition: deep layer of the abdomen that has fascicles arranged transversely around the abdomen

trapezius.definition: muscle that stabilizes the upper part of the back

triceps brachii.definition: three-headed muscle that extends the forearm

unipennate.definition: pennate muscle that has fascicles located on one side of the tendon

urogenital triangle.definition: anterior triangle of the perineum that includes the external genitals

vastus intermedius.definition: quadricep muscle that is between the vastus lateralis and vastus medialis and is deep to the rectus femoris

vastus lateralis.definition: quadricep muscle on the lateral aspect of the thigh

vastus medialis.definition: quadricep muscle on the medial aspect of the thigh

absolute refractory period.definition: time during an action period when another action potential cannot be generated because the voltage-gated Na+channel is inactivated

action potential.definition: change in voltage of a cell membrane in response to a stimulus that results in transmission of an electrical signal; unique to neurons and muscle fibers

activation gate.definition: part of the voltage-gated Na+channel that opens when the membrane voltage reaches threshold

astrocyte.definition: glial cell type of the CNS that provides support for neurons and maintains the blood-brain barrier

autonomic nervous system (ANS).definition: functional division of the nervous system that is responsible for homeostatic reflexes that coordinate control of cardiac and smooth muscle, as well as glandular tissue

axon.definition: single process of the neuron that carries an electrical signal (action potential) away from the cell body toward a target cell

axon hillock.definition: tapering of the neuron cell body that gives rise to the axon

axon segment.definition: single stretch of the axon insulated by myelin and bounded by nodes of Ranvier at either end (except for the first, which is after the initial segment, and the last, which is followed by the axon terminal)

axon terminal.definition: end of the axon, where there are usually several branches extending toward the target cell

axoplasm.definition: cytoplasm of an axon, which is different in composition than the cytoplasm of the neuronal cell body

biogenic amine.definition: class of neurotransmitters that are enzymatically derived from amino acids but no longer contain a carboxyl group

bipolar.definition: shape of a neuron with two processes extending from the neuron cell bodyâthe axon and one dendrite

blood-brain barrier (BBB).definition: physiological barrier between the circulatory system and the central nervous system that establishes a privileged blood supply, restricting the flow of substances into the CNS

brain.definition: the large organ of the central nervous system composed of white and gray matter, contained within the cranium and continuous with the spinal cord

central nervous system (CNS).definition: anatomical division of the nervous system located within the cranial and vertebral cavities, namely the brain and spinal cord

cerebral cortex.definition: outermost layer of gray matter in the brain, where conscious perception takes place

cerebrospinal fluid (CSF).definition: circulatory medium within the CNS that is produced by ependymal cells in the choroid plexus filtering the blood

chemical synapse.definition: connection between two neurons, or between a neuron and its target, where a neurotransmitter diffuses across a very short distance

cholinergic system.definition: neurotransmitter system of acetylcholine, which includes its receptors and the enzyme acetylcholinesterase

choroid plexus.definition: specialized structure containing ependymal cells that line blood capillaries and filter blood to produce CSF in the four ventricles of the brain

continuous conduction.definition: slow propagation of an action potential along an unmyelinated axon owing to voltage-gated Na+channels located along the entire length of the cell membrane

dendrite.definition: one of many branchlike processes that extends from the neuron cell body and functions as a contact for incoming signals (synapses) from other neurons or sensory cells

depolarization.definition: change in a cell membrane potential from rest toward zero

effector protein.definition: enzyme that catalyzes the generation of a new molecule, which acts as the intracellular mediator of the signal that binds to the receptor

electrical synapse.definition: connection between two neurons, or any two electrically active cells, where ions flow directly through channels spanning their adjacent cell membranes

electrochemical exclusion.definition: principle of selectively allowing ions through a channel on the basis of their charge

enteric nervous system (ENS).definition: neural tissue associated with the digestive system that is responsible for nervous control through autonomic connections

ependymal cell.definition: glial cell type in the CNS responsible for producing cerebrospinal fluid

excitable membrane.definition: cell membrane that regulates the movement of ions so that an electrical signal can be generated

excitatory postsynaptic potential (EPSP).definition: graded potential in the postsynaptic membrane that is the result of depolarization and makes an action potential more likely to occur

G protein.definition: guanosine triphosphate (GTP) hydrolase that physically moves from the receptor protein to the effector protein to activate the latter

ganglion.definition: localized collection of neuron cell bodies in the peripheral nervous system

gated.definition: property of a channel that determines how it opens under specific conditions, such as voltage change or physical deformation

generator potential.definition: graded potential from dendrites of a unipolar cell which generates the action potential in the initial segment of that cellâs axon

glial cell.definition: one of the various types of neural tissue cells responsible for maintenance of the tissue, and largely responsible for supporting neurons

graded potential.definition: change in the membrane potential that varies in size, depending on the size of the stimulus that elicits it

gray matter.definition: regions of the nervous system containing cell bodies of neurons with few or no myelinated axons; actually may be more pink or tan in color, but called gray in contrast to white matter

inactivation gate.definition: part of a voltage-gated Na+channel that closes when the membrane potential reaches +30 mV

inhibitory postsynaptic potential (IPSP).definition: graded potential in the postsynaptic membrane that is the result of hyperpolarization and makes an action potential less likely to occur

initial segment.definition: first part of the axon as it emerges from the axon hillock, where the electrical signals known as action potentials are generated

integration.definition: nervous system function that combines sensory perceptions and higher cognitive functions (memories, learning, emotion, etc.) to produce a response

ionotropic receptor.definition: neurotransmitter receptor that acts as an ion channel gate, and opens by the binding of the neurotransmitter

leakage channel.definition: ion channel that opens randomly and is not gated to a specific event, also known as a non-gated channel

ligand-gated channels.definition: another name for an ionotropic receptor for which a neurotransmitter is the ligand

lower motor neuron.definition: second neuron in the motor command pathway that is directly connected to the skeletal muscle

mechanically gated channel.definition: ion channel that opens when a physical event directly affects the structure of the protein

membrane potential.definition: distribution of charge across the cell membrane, based on the charges of ions

metabotropic receptor.definition: neurotransmitter receptor that involves a complex of proteins that cause metabolic changes in a cell

microglia.definition: glial cell type in the CNS that serves as the resident component of the immune system

multipolar.definition: shape of a neuron that has multiple processesâthe axon and two or more dendrites

muscarinic receptor.definition: type of acetylcholine receptor protein that is characterized by also binding to muscarine and is a metabotropic receptor

myelin.definition: lipid-rich insulating substance surrounding the axons of many neurons, allowing for faster transmission of electrical signals

myelin sheath.definition: lipid-rich layer of insulation that surrounds an axon, formed by oligodendrocytes in the CNS and Schwann cells in the PNS; facilitates the transmission of electrical signals

nerve.definition: cord-like bundle of axons located in the peripheral nervous system that transmits sensory input and response output to and from the central nervous system

neuron.definition: neural tissue cell that is primarily responsible for generating and propagating electrical signals into, within, and out of the nervous system

neuropeptide.definition: neurotransmitter type that includes protein molecules and shorter chains of amino acids

neurotransmitter.definition: chemical signal that is released from the synaptic end bulb of a neuron to cause a change in the target cell

nicotinic receptor.definition: type of acetylcholine receptor protein that is characterized by also binding to nicotine and is an ionotropic receptor

node of Ranvier.definition: gap between two myelinated regions of an axon, allowing for strengthening of the electrical signal as it propagates down the axon

nonspecific channel.definition: channel that is not specific to one ion over another, such as a nonspecific cation channel that allows any positively charged ion across the membrane

nucleus.definition: in the nervous system, a localized collection of neuron cell bodies that are functionally related; a âcenterâ of neural function

oligodendrocyte.definition: glial cell type in the CNS that provides the myelin insulation for axons in tracts

peripheral nervous system (PNS).definition: anatomical division of the nervous system that is largely outside the cranial and vertebral cavities, namely all parts except the brain and spinal cord

postsynaptic potential (PSP).definition: graded potential in the postsynaptic membrane caused by the binding of neurotransmitter to protein receptors

precentral gyrus of the frontal cortex.definition: region of the cerebral cortex responsible for generating motor commands, where the upper motor neuron cell body is located

process.definition: in cells, an extension of a cell body; in the case of neurons, this includes the axon and dendrites

propagation.definition: movement of an action potential along the length of an axon

receptor potential.definition: graded potential in a specialized sensory cell that directly causes the release of neurotransmitter without an intervening action potential

refractory period.definition: time after the initiation of an action potential when another action potential cannot be generated

relative refractory period.definition: time during the refractory period when a new action potential can only be initiated by a stronger stimulus than the current action potential because voltage-gated K+channels are not closed

repolarization.definition: return of the membrane potential to its normally negative voltage at the end of the action potential

resistance.definition: property of an axon that relates to the ability of particles to diffuse through the cytoplasm; this is inversely proportional to the fiber diameter

response.definition: nervous system function that causes a target tissue (muscle or gland) to produce an event as a consequence to stimuli

resting membrane potential.definition: the difference in voltage measured across a cell membrane under steady-state conditions, typically -70 mV

saltatory conduction.definition: quick propagation of the action potential along a myelinated axon owing to voltage-gated Na+channels being present only at the nodes of Ranvier

satellite cell.definition: glial cell type in the PNS that provides support for neurons in the ganglia

Schwann cell.definition: glial cell type in the PNS that provides the myelin insulation for axons in nerves

sensation.definition: nervous system function that receives information from the environment and translates it into the electrical signals of nervous tissue

size exclusion.definition: principle of selectively allowing ions through a channel on the basis of their relative size

soma.definition: in neurons, that portion of the cell that contains the nucleus; the cell body, as opposed to the cell processes (axons and dendrites)

somatic nervous system (SNS).definition: functional division of the nervous system that is concerned with conscious perception, voluntary movement, and skeletal muscle reflexes

spatial summation.definition: combination of graded potentials across the neuronal cell membrane caused by signals from separate presynaptic elements that add up to initiate an action potential

spinal cord.definition: organ of the central nervous system found within the vertebral cavity and connected with the periphery through spinal nerves; mediates reflex behaviors

stimulus.definition: an event in the external or internal environment that registers as activity in a sensory neuron

summate.definition: to add together, as in the cumulative change in postsynaptic potentials toward reaching threshold in the membrane, either across a span of the membrane or over a certain amount of time

synapse.definition: narrow junction across which a chemical signal passes from neuron to the next, initiating a new electrical signal in the target cell

synaptic cleft.definition: small gap between cells in a chemical synapse where neurotransmitter diffuses from the presynaptic element to the postsynaptic element

synaptic end bulb.definition: swelling at the end of an axon where neurotransmitter molecules are released onto a target cell across a synapse

temporal summation.definition: combination of graded potentials at the same location on a neuron resulting in a strong signal from one input

thalamus.definition: region of the central nervous system that acts as a relay for sensory pathways

thermoreceptor.definition: type of sensory receptor capable of transducing temperature stimuli into neural action potentials

threshold.definition: membrane voltage at which an action potential is initiated

tract.definition: bundle of axons in the central nervous system having the same function and point of origin

unipolar.definition: shape of a neuron which has only one process that includes both the axon and dendrite

upper motor neuron.definition: first neuron in the motor command pathway with its cell body in the cerebral cortex that synapses on the lower motor neuron in the spinal cord

ventricle.definition: central cavity within the brain where CSF is produced and circulates

voltage-gated channel.definition: ion channel that opens because of a change in the charge distributed across the membrane where it is located

white matter.definition: regions of the nervous system containing mostly myelinated axons, making the tissue appear white because of the high lipid content of myelin

abducens nerve.definition: sixth cranial nerve; responsible for contraction of one of the extraocular muscles

alar plate.definition: developmental region of the spinal cord that gives rise to the posterior horn of the gray matter

amygdala.definition: nucleus deep in the temporal lobe of the cerebrum that is related to memory and emotional behavior

anterior column.definition: white matter between the anterior horns of the spinal cord composed of many different groups of axons of both ascending and descending tracts

anterior horn.definition: gray matter of the spinal cord containing multipolar motor neurons, sometimes referred to as the ventral horn

anterior median fissure.definition: deep midline feature of the anterior spinal cord, marking the separation between the right and left sides of the cord

anterior spinal artery.definition: blood vessel from the merged branches of the vertebral arteries that runs along the anterior surface of the spinal cord

arachnoid granulation.definition: outpocket of the arachnoid membrane into the dural sinuses that allows for reabsorption of CSF into the blood

arachnoid mater.definition: middle layer of the meninges named for the spider-webâlike trabeculae that extend between it and the pia mater

arachnoid trabeculae.definition: filaments between the arachnoid and pia mater within the subarachnoid space

ascending tract.definition: central nervous system fibers carrying sensory information from the spinal cord or periphery to the brain

axillary nerve.definition: systemic nerve of the arm that arises from the brachial plexus

basal forebrain.definition: nuclei of the cerebrum related to modulation of sensory stimuli and attention through broad projections to the cerebral cortex, loss of which is related to Alzheimerâs disease

basal nuclei.definition: nuclei of the cerebrum (with a few components in the upper brain stem and diencephalon) that are responsible for assessing cortical movement commands and comparing them with the general state of the individual through broad modulatory activity of dopamine neurons; largely related to motor functions, as evidenced through the symptoms of Parkinsonâs and Huntingtonâs diseases

basal plate.definition: developmental region of the spinal cord that gives rise to the lateral and anterior horns of gray matter

basilar artery.definition: blood vessel from the merged vertebral arteries that runs along the dorsal surface of the brain stem

brachial plexus.definition: nerve plexus associated with the lower cervical spinal nerves and first thoracic spinal nerve

brain stem.definition: region of the adult brain that includes the midbrain, pons, and medulla oblongata and develops from the mesencephalon, metencephalon, and myelencephalon of the embryonic brain

Broca\u00e2\u0080\u0099s area.definition: region of the frontal lobe associated with the motor commands necessary for speech production and located only in the cerebral hemisphere responsible for language production, which is the left side in approximately 95 percent of the population

Brodmann\u00e2\u0080\u0099s areas.definition: mapping of regions of the cerebral cortex based on microscopic anatomy that relates specific areas to functional differences, as described by Brodmann in the early 1900s

carotid canal.definition: opening in the temporal bone through which the internal carotid artery enters the cranium

cauda equina.definition: bundle of spinal nerve roots that descend from the lower spinal cord below the first lumbar vertebra and lie within the vertebral cavity; has the appearance of a horse's tail

caudate.definition: nucleus deep in the cerebrum that is part of the basal nuclei; along with the putamen, it is part of the striatum

central canal.definition: hollow space within the spinal cord that is the remnant of the center of the neural tube

central sulcus.definition: surface landmark of the cerebral cortex that marks the boundary between the frontal and parietal lobes

cephalic flexure.definition: curve in midbrain of the embryo that positions the forebrain ventrally

cerebellum.definition: region of the adult brain connected primarily to the pons that developed from the metencephalon (along with the pons) and is largely responsible for comparing information from the cerebrum with sensory feedback from the periphery through the spinal cord

cerebral aqueduct.definition: connection of the ventricular system between the third and fourth ventricles located in the midbrain

cerebral cortex.definition: outer gray matter covering the forebrain, marked by wrinkles and folds known as gyri and sulci

cerebral hemisphere.definition: one half of the bilaterally symmetrical cerebrum

cerebrum.definition: region of the adult brain that develops from the telencephalon and is responsible for higher neurological functions such as memory, emotion, and consciousness

cervical plexus.definition: nerve plexus associated with the upper cervical spinal nerves

choroid plexus.definition: specialized structures containing ependymal cells lining blood capillaries that filter blood to produce CSF in the four ventricles of the brain

circle of Willis.definition: unique anatomical arrangement of blood vessels around the base of the brain that maintains perfusion of blood into the brain even if one component of the structure is blocked or narrowed

common carotid artery.definition: blood vessel that branches off the aorta (or the brachiocephalic artery on the right) and supplies blood to the head and neck

corpus callosum.definition: large white matter structure that connects the right and left cerebral hemispheres

cranial nerve.definition: one of twelve nerves connected to the brain that are responsible for sensory or motor functions of the head and neck

descending tract.definition: central nervous system fibers carrying motor commands from the brain to the spinal cord or periphery

diencephalon.definition: region of the adult brain that retains its name from embryonic development and includes the thalamus and hypothalamus

direct pathway.definition: connections within the basal nuclei from the striatum to the globus pallidus internal segment and substantia nigra pars reticulata that disinhibit the thalamus to increase cortical control of movement

disinhibition.definition: disynaptic connection in which the first synapse inhibits the second cell, which then stops inhibiting the final target

dorsal (posterior) nerve root.definition: axons entering the posterior horn of the spinal cord

dorsal (posterior) root ganglion.definition: sensory ganglion attached to the posterior nerve root of a spinal nerve

dura mater.definition: tough, fibrous, outer layer of the meninges that is attached to the inner surface of the cranium and vertebral column and surrounds the entire CNS

dural sinus.definition: any of the venous structures surrounding the brain, enclosed within the dura mater, which drain blood from the CNS to the common venous return of the jugular veins

endoneurium.definition: innermost layer of connective tissue that surrounds individual axons within a nerve

enteric nervous system.definition: peripheral structures, namely ganglia and nerves, that are incorporated into the digestive system organs

enteric plexus.definition: neuronal plexus in the wall of the intestines, which is part of the enteric nervous system

epineurium.definition: outermost layer of connective tissue that surrounds an entire nerve

epithalamus.definition: region of the diecephalon containing the pineal gland

esophageal plexus.definition: neuronal plexus in the wall of the esophagus that is part of the enteric nervous system

extraocular muscles.definition: six skeletal muscles that control eye movement within the orbit

facial nerve.definition: seventh cranial nerve; responsible for contraction of the facial muscles and for part of the sense of taste, as well as causing saliva production

fascicle.definition: small bundles of nerve or muscle fibers enclosed by connective tissue

femoral nerve.definition: systemic nerve of the anterior leg that arises from the lumbar plexus

fibular nerve.definition: systemic nerve of the posterior leg that begins as part of the sciatic nerve

foramen magnum.definition: large opening in the occipital bone of the skull through which the spinal cord emerges and the vertebral arteries enter the cranium

forebrain.definition: anterior region of the adult brain that develops from the prosencephalon and includes the cerebrum and diencephalon

fourth ventricle.definition: the portion of the ventricular system that is in the region of the brain stem and opens into the subarachnoid space through the median and lateral apertures

frontal eye field.definition: region of the frontal lobe associated with motor commands to orient the eyes toward an object of visual attention

frontal lobe.definition: region of the cerebral cortex directly beneath the frontal bone of the cranium

gastric plexuses.definition: neuronal networks in the wall of the stomach that are part of the enteric nervous system

globus pallidus.definition: nuclei deep in the cerebrum that are part of the basal nuclei and can be divided into the internal and external segments

glossopharyngeal nerve.definition: ninth cranial nerve; responsible for contraction of muscles in the tongue and throat and for part of the sense of taste, as well as causing saliva production

gyrus.definition: ridge formed by convolutions on the surface of the cerebrum or cerebellum

hindbrain.definition: posterior region of the adult brain that develops from the rhombencephalon and includes the pons, medulla oblongata, and cerebellum

hippocampus.definition: gray matter deep in the temporal lobe that is very important for long-term memory formation

hypoglossal nerve.definition: twelfth cranial nerve; responsible for contraction of muscles of the tongue

hypothalamus.definition: major region of the diencephalon that is responsible for coordinating autonomic and endocrine control of homeostasis

indirect pathway.definition: connections within the basal nuclei from the striatum through the globus pallidus external segment and subthalamic nucleus to the globus pallidus internal segment/substantia nigra pars compacta that result in inhibition of the thalamus to decrease cortical control of movement

inferior colliculus.definition: half of the midbrain tectum that is part of the brain stem auditory pathway

inferior olive.definition: nucleus in the medulla that is involved in processing information related to motor control

intercostal nerve.definition: systemic nerve in the thoracic cavity that is found between two ribs

internal carotid artery.definition: branch from the common carotid artery that enters the cranium and supplies blood to the brain

interventricular foramina.definition: openings between the lateral ventricles and third ventricle allowing for the passage of CSF

jugular veins.definition: blood vessels that return âusedâ blood from the head and neck

kinesthesia.definition: general sensory perception of movement of the body

lateral apertures.definition: pair of openings from the fourth ventricle to the subarachnoid space on either side and between the medulla and cerebellum

lateral column.definition: white matter of the spinal cord between the posterior horn on one side and the axons from the anterior horn on the same side; composed of many different groups of axons, of both ascending and descending tracts, carrying motor commands to and from the brain

lateral horn.definition: region of the spinal cord gray matter in the thoracic, upper lumbar, and sacral regions that is the central component of the sympathetic division of the autonomic nervous system

lateral sulcus.definition: surface landmark of the cerebral cortex that marks the boundary between the temporal lobe and the frontal and parietal lobes

lateral ventricles.definition: portions of the ventricular system that are in the region of the cerebrum

limbic cortex.definition: collection of structures of the cerebral cortex that are involved in emotion, memory, and behavior and are part of the larger limbic system

limbic system.definition: structures at the edge (limit) of the boundary between the forebrain and hindbrain that are most associated with emotional behavior and memory formation

longitudinal fissure.definition: large separation along the midline between the two cerebral hemispheres

lumbar plexus.definition: nerve plexus associated with the lumbar spinal nerves

lumbar puncture.definition: procedure used to withdraw CSF from the lower lumbar region of the vertebral column that avoids the risk of damaging CNS tissue because the spinal cord ends at the upper lumbar vertebrae

median aperture.definition: singular opening from the fourth ventricle into the subarachnoid space at the midline between the medulla and cerebellum

median nerve.definition: systemic nerve of the arm, located between the ulnar and radial nerves

meninges.definition: protective outer coverings of the CNS composed of connective tissue

mesencephalon.definition: primary vesicle of the embryonic brain that does not significantly change through the rest of embryonic development and becomes the midbrain

metencephalon.definition: secondary vesicle of the embryonic brain that develops into the pons and the cerebellum

midbrain.definition: middle region of the adult brain that develops from the mesencephalon

myelencephalon.definition: secondary vesicle of the embryonic brain that develops into the medulla

nerve plexus.definition: network of nerves without neuronal cell bodies included

neural crest.definition: tissue that detaches from the edges of the neural groove and migrates through the embryo to develop into peripheral structures of both nervous and non-nervous tissues

neural fold.definition: elevated edge of the neural groove

neural groove.definition: region of the neural plate that folds into the dorsal surface of the embryo and closes off to become the neural tube

neural plate.definition: thickened layer of neuroepithelium that runs longitudinally along the dorsal surface of an embryo and gives rise to nervous system tissue

neural tube.definition: precursor to structures of the central nervous system, formed by the invagination and separation of neuroepithelium

neuraxis.definition: central axis to the nervous system, from the posterior to anterior ends of the neural tube; the inferior tip of the spinal cord to the anterior surface of the cerebrum

occipital lobe.definition: region of the cerebral cortex directly beneath the occipital bone of the cranium

occipital sinuses.definition: dural sinuses along the edge of the occipital lobes of the cerebrum

oculomotor nerve.definition: third cranial nerve; responsible for contraction of four of the extraocular muscles, the muscle in the upper eyelid, and pupillary constriction

olfaction.definition: special sense responsible for smell, which has a unique, direct connection to the cerebrum

olfactory nerve.definition: first cranial nerve; responsible for the sense of smell

optic nerve.definition: second cranial nerve; responsible for visual sensation

orthostatic reflex.definition: sympathetic function that maintains blood pressure when standing to offset the increased effect of gravity

paravertebral ganglia.definition: autonomic ganglia superior to the sympathetic chain ganglia

parietal lobe.definition: region of the cerebral cortex directly beneath the parietal bone of the cranium

parieto-occipital sulcus.definition: groove in the cerebral cortex representing the border between the parietal and occipital cortices

perineurium.definition: layer of connective tissue surrounding fascicles within a nerve

phrenic nerve.definition: systemic nerve from the cervical plexus that innervates the diaphragm

pia mater.definition: thin, innermost membrane of the meninges that directly covers the surface of the CNS

plexus.definition: network of nerves or nervous tissue

postcentral gyrus.definition: ridge just posterior to the central sulcus, in the parietal lobe, where somatosensory processing initially takes place in the cerebrum

posterior columns.definition: white matter of the spinal cord that lies between the posterior horns of the gray matter, sometimes referred to as the dorsal column; composed of axons of ascending tracts that carry sensory information up to the brain

posterior horn.definition: gray matter region of the spinal cord in which sensory input arrives, sometimes referred to as the dorsal horn

posterior median sulcus.definition: midline feature of the posterior spinal cord, marking the separation between right and left sides of the cord

posterolateral sulcus.definition: feature of the posterior spinal cord marking the entry of posterior nerve roots and the separation between the posterior and lateral columns of the white matter

precentral gyrus.definition: ridge just anterior to the central sulcus, in the frontal lobe, the primary motor cortex is located

prefrontal lobe.definition: specific region of the frontal lobe anterior to the more specific motor function areas, which can be related to the early planning of movements and intentions to the point of being personality-type functions

premotor area.definition: region of the frontal lobe responsible for planning movements that will be executed through the primary motor cortex

prevertebral ganglia.definition: autonomic ganglia that are anterior to the vertebral column and functionally related to the sympathetic chain ganglia

primary vesicle.definition: initial enlargements of the anterior neural tube during embryonic development that develop into the forebrain, midbrain, and hindbrain

proprioception.definition: general sensory perceptions providing information about location and movement of body parts; the âsense of the selfâ

prosencephalon.definition: primary vesicle of the embryonic brain that develops into the forebrain, which includes the cerebrum and diencephalon

putamen.definition: nucleus deep in the cerebrum that is part of the basal nuclei; along with the caudate, it is part of the striatum

radial nerve.definition: systemic nerve of the arm, the distal component of which is located near the radial bone

reticular formation.definition: diffuse region of gray matter throughout the brain stem that regulates sleep, wakefulness, and states of consciousness

rhombencephalon.definition: primary vesicle of the embryonic brain that develops into the hindbrain, which includes the pons, cerebellum, and medulla

sacral plexus.definition: nerve plexus associated with the lower lumbar and sacral spinal nerves

saphenous nerve.definition: systemic nerve of the lower anterior leg that is a branch from the femoral nerve

sciatic nerve.definition: systemic nerve from the sacral plexus that is a combination of the tibial and fibular nerves and extends across the hip joint and gluteal region into the upper posterior leg

sciatica.definition: painful condition resulting from inflammation or compression of the sciatic nerve or any of the spinal nerves that contribute to it

secondary vesicle.definition: five vesicles that develop from primary vesicles, continuing the process of differentiation of the embryonic brain

sigmoid sinuses.definition: dural sinuses that drain directly into the jugular veins

somatosensation.definition: general senses related to the body, usually thought of as the senses of touch, which would include pain, temperature, and proprioception

spinal accessory nerve.definition: eleventh cranial nerve; responsible for contraction of neck muscles

spinal nerve.definition: one of 31 nerves connected to the spinal cord

straight sinus.definition: dural sinus that drains blood from the deep center of the brain to collect with the other sinuses

striatum.definition: the caudate and putamen collectively, as part of the basal nuclei, which receive input from the cerebral cortex

subarachnoid space.definition: space between the arachnoid mater and pia mater that contains CSF and the fibrous connections of the arachnoid trabeculae

subcortical nucleus.definition: all the nuclei beneath the cerebral cortex, including the basal nuclei and the basal forebrain

substantia nigra pars compacta.definition: nuclei within the basal nuclei that release dopamine to modulate the function of the striatum; part of the motor pathway

substantia nigra pars reticulata.definition: nuclei within the basal nuclei that serve as an output center of the nuclei; part of the motor pathway

subthalamus.definition: nucleus within the basal nuclei that is part of the indirect pathway

sulcus.definition: groove formed by convolutions in the surface of the cerebral cortex

superior colliculus.definition: half of the midbrain tectum that is responsible for aligning visual, auditory, and somatosensory spatial perceptions

superior sagittal sinus.definition: dural sinus that runs along the top of the longitudinal fissure and drains blood from the majority of the outer cerebrum

sympathetic chain ganglia.definition: autonomic ganglia in a chain along the anterolateral aspect of the vertebral column that are responsible for contributing to homeostatic mechanisms of the autonomic nervous system

systemic nerve.definition: nerve in the periphery distal to a nerve plexus or spinal nerve

tectum.definition: region of the midbrain, thought of as the roof of the cerebral aqueduct, which is subdivided into the inferior and superior colliculi

tegmentum.definition: region of the midbrain, thought of as the floor of the cerebral aqueduct, which continues into the pons and medulla as the floor of the fourth ventricle

telencephalon.definition: secondary vesicle of the embryonic brain that develops into the cerebrum

temporal lobe.definition: region of the cerebral cortex directly beneath the temporal bone of the cranium

terminal ganglion.definition: autonomic ganglia that are near or within the walls of organs that are responsible for contributing to homeostatic mechanisms of the autonomic nervous system

thalamus.definition: major region of the diencephalon that is responsible for relaying information between the cerebrum and the hindbrain, spinal cord, and periphery

third ventricle.definition: portion of the ventricular system that is in the region of the diencephalon

tibial nerve.definition: systemic nerve of the posterior leg that begins as part of the sciatic nerve

transverse sinuses.definition: dural sinuses that drain along either side of the occipitalâcerebellar space

trigeminal ganglion.definition: sensory ganglion that contributes sensory fibers to the trigeminal nerve

trigeminal nerve.definition: fifth cranial nerve; responsible for cutaneous sensation of the face and contraction of the muscles of mastication

trochlear nerve.definition: fourth cranial nerve; responsible for contraction of one of the extraocular muscles

ulnar nerve.definition: systemic nerve of the arm located close to the ulna, a bone of the forearm

vagus nerve.definition: tenth cranial nerve; responsible for the autonomic control of organs in the thoracic and upper abdominal cavities

ventral (anterior) nerve root.definition: axons emerging from the anterior or lateral horns of the spinal cord

ventricles.definition: remnants of the hollow center of the neural tube that are spaces for cerebrospinal fluid to circulate through the brain

vertebral arteries.definition: arteries that ascend along either side of the vertebral column through the transverse foramina of the cervical vertebrae and enter the cranium through the foramen magnum

vestibulocochlear nerve.definition: eighth cranial nerve; responsible for the sensations of hearing and balance

alkaloid.definition: substance, usually from a plant source, that is chemically basic with respect to pH and will stimulate bitter receptors

amacrine cell.definition: type of cell in the retina that connects to the bipolar cells near the outer synaptic layer and provides the basis for early image processing within the retina

ampulla.definition: in the ear, the structure at the base of a semicircular canal that contains the hair cells and cupula for transduction of rotational movement of the head

anosmia.definition: loss of the sense of smell; usually the result of physical disruption of the first cranial nerve

anterior corticospinal tract.definition: division of the corticospinal pathway that travels through the ventral (anterior) column of the spinal cord and controls axial musculature through the medial motor neurons in the ventral (anterior) horn

aqueous humor.definition: watery fluid that fills the anterior chamber containing the cornea, iris, ciliary body, and lens of the eye

ascending pathway.definition: fiber structure that relays sensory information from the periphery through the spinal cord and brain stem to other structures of the brain

association area.definition: region of cortex connected to a primary sensory cortical area that further processes the information to generate more complex sensory perceptions

auricle.definition: fleshy external structure of the ear

basilar membrane.definition: in the ear, the floor of the cochlear duct on which the organ of Corti sits

Betz cells.definition: output cells of the primary motor cortex that cause musculature to move through synapses on cranial and spinal motor neurons

binocular depth cues.definition: indications of the distance of visual stimuli on the basis of slight differences in the images projected onto either retina

bipolar cell.definition: cell type in the retina that connects the photoreceptors to the RGCs

Broca\u00e2\u0080\u0099s area.definition: region of the frontal lobe associated with the motor commands necessary for speech production

capsaicin.definition: molecule that activates nociceptors by interacting with a temperature-sensitive ion channel and is the basis for âhotâ sensations in spicy food

cerebral peduncles.definition: segments of the descending motor pathway that make up the white matter of the ventral midbrain

cervical enlargement.definition: region of the ventral (anterior) horn of the spinal cord that has a larger population of motor neurons for the greater number of and finer control of muscles of the upper limb

chemoreceptor.definition: sensory receptor cell that is sensitive to chemical stimuli, such as in taste, smell, or pain

chief sensory nucleus.definition: component of the trigeminal nuclei that is found in the pons

choroid.definition: highly vascular tissue in the wall of the eye that supplies the outer retina with blood

ciliary body.definition: smooth muscle structure on the interior surface of the iris that controls the shape of the lens through the zonule fibers

circadian rhythm.definition: internal perception of the daily cycle of light and dark based on retinal activity related to sunlight

cochlea.definition: auditory portion of the inner ear containing structures to transduce sound stimuli

cochlear duct.definition: space within the auditory portion of the inner ear that contains the organ of Corti and is adjacent to the scala tympani and scala vestibuli on either side

cone photoreceptor.definition: one of the two types of retinal receptor cell that is specialized for color vision through the use of three photopigments distributed through three separate populations of cells

contralateral.definition: word meaning âon the opposite side,â as in axons that cross the midline in a fiber tract

cornea.definition: fibrous covering of the anterior region of the eye that is transparent so that light can pass through it

corneal reflex.definition: protective response to stimulation of the cornea causing contraction of the orbicularis oculi muscle resulting in blinking of the eye

corticobulbar tract.definition: connection between the cortex and the brain stem responsible for generating movement

corticospinal tract.definition: connection between the cortex and the spinal cord responsible for generating movement

cupula.definition: specialized structure within the base of a semicircular canal that bends the stereocilia of hair cells when the head rotates by way of the relative movement of the enclosed fluid

decussate.definition: to cross the midline, as in fibers that project from one side of the body to the other

dorsal column system.definition: ascending tract of the spinal cord associated with fine touch and proprioceptive sensations

dorsal stream.definition: connections between cortical areas from the occipital to parietal lobes that are responsible for the perception of visual motion and guiding movement of the body in relation to that motion

encapsulated ending.definition: configuration of a sensory receptor neuron with dendrites surrounded by specialized structures to aid in transduction of a particular type of sensation, such as the lamellated corpuscles in the deep dermis and subcutaneous tissue

equilibrium.definition: sense of balance that includes sensations of position and movement of the head

executive functions.definition: cognitive processes of the prefrontal cortex that lead to directing goal-directed behavior, which is a precursor to executing motor commands

external ear.definition: structures on the lateral surface of the head, including the auricle and the ear canal back to the tympanic membrane

exteroceptor.definition: sensory receptor that is positioned to interpret stimuli from the external environment, such as photoreceptors in the eye or somatosensory receptors in the skin

extraocular muscle.definition: one of six muscles originating out of the bones of the orbit and inserting into the surface of the eye which are responsible for moving the eye

extrapyramidal system.definition: pathways between the brain and spinal cord that are separate from the corticospinal tract and are responsible for modulating the movements generated through that primary pathway

fasciculus cuneatus.definition: lateral division of the dorsal column system composed of fibers from sensory neurons in the upper body

fasciculus gracilis.definition: medial division of the dorsal column system composed of fibers from sensory neurons in the lower body

fibrous tunic.definition: outer layer of the eye primarily composed of connective tissue known as the sclera and cornea

fovea.definition: exact center of the retina at which visual stimuli are focused for maximal acuity, where the retina is thinnest, at which there is nothing but photoreceptors

free nerve ending.definition: configuration of a sensory receptor neuron with dendrites in the connective tissue of the organ, such as in the dermis of the skin, that are most often sensitive to chemical, thermal, and mechanical stimuli

frontal eye fields.definition: area of the prefrontal cortex responsible for moving the eyes to attend to visual stimuli

general sense.definition: any sensory system that is distributed throughout the body and incorporated into organs of multiple other systems, such as the walls of the digestive organs or the skin

gustatory receptor cells.definition: sensory cells in the taste bud that transduce the chemical stimuli of gustation

hair cells.definition: mechanoreceptor cells found in the inner ear that transduce stimuli for the senses of hearing and balance

incus.definition: (also, anvil) ossicle of the middle ear that connects the malleus to the stapes

inferior colliculus.definition: last structure in the auditory brainstem pathway that projects to the thalamus and superior colliculus

inferior oblique.definition: extraocular muscle responsible for lateral rotation of the eye

inferior rectus.definition: extraocular muscle responsible for looking down

inner ear.definition: structure within the temporal bone that contains the sensory apparati of hearing and balance

inner segment.definition: in the eye, the section of a photoreceptor that contains the nucleus and other major organelles for normal cellular functions

inner synaptic layer.definition: layer in the retina where bipolar cells connect to RGCs

interaural intensity difference.definition: cue used to aid sound localization in the horizontal plane that compares the relative loudness of sounds at the two ears, because the ear closer to the sound source will hear a slightly more intense sound

interaural time difference.definition: cue used to help with sound localization in the horizontal plane that compares the relative time of arrival of sounds at the two ears, because the ear closer to the sound source will receive the stimulus microseconds before the other ear

internal capsule.definition: segment of the descending motor pathway that passes between the caudate nucleus and the putamen

interoceptor.definition: sensory receptor that is positioned to interpret stimuli from internal organs, such as stretch receptors in the wall of blood vessels

ipsilateral.definition: word meaning on the same side, as in axons that do not cross the midline in a fiber tract

iris.definition: colored portion of the anterior eye that surrounds the pupil

kinesthesia.definition: sense of body movement based on sensations in skeletal muscles, tendons, joints, and the skin

lacrimal duct.definition: duct in the medial corner of the orbit that drains tears into the nasal cavity

lacrimal gland.definition: gland lateral to the orbit that produces tears to wash across the surface of the eye

lateral corticospinal tract.definition: division of the corticospinal pathway that travels through the lateral column of the spinal cord and controls appendicular musculature through the lateral motor neurons in the ventral (anterior) horn

lateral geniculate nucleus.definition: thalamic target of the RGCs that projects to the visual cortex

lateral rectus.definition: extraocular muscle responsible for abduction of the eye

lens.definition: component of the eye that focuses light on the retina

levator palpebrae superioris.definition: muscle that causes elevation of the upper eyelid, controlled by fibers in the oculomotor nerve

lumbar enlargement.definition: region of the ventral (anterior) horn of the spinal cord that has a larger population of motor neurons for the greater number of muscles of the lower limb

macula.definition: enlargement at the base of a semicircular canal at which transduction of equilibrium stimuli takes place within the ampulla

malleus.definition: (also, hammer) ossicle that is directly attached to the tympanic membrane

mechanoreceptor.definition: receptor cell that transduces mechanical stimuli into an electrochemical signal

medial geniculate nucleus.definition: thalamic target of the auditory brain stem that projects to the auditory cortex

medial lemniscus.definition: fiber tract of the dorsal column system that extends from the nuclei gracilis and cuneatus to the thalamus, and decussates

medial rectus.definition: extraocular muscle responsible for adduction of the eye

mesencephalic nucleus.definition: component of the trigeminal nuclei that is found in the midbrain

middle ear.definition: space within the temporal bone between the ear canal and bony labyrinth where the ossicles amplify sound waves from the tympanic membrane to the oval window
