multimodal integration area.definition: region of the cerebral cortex in which information from more than one sensory modality is processed to arrive at higher level cortical functions such as memory, learning, or cognition

neural tunic.definition: layer of the eye that contains nervous tissue, namely the retina

nociceptor.definition: receptor cell that senses pain stimuli

nucleus cuneatus.definition: medullary nucleus at which first-order neurons of the dorsal column system synapse specifically from the upper body and arms

nucleus gracilis.definition: medullary nucleus at which first-order neurons of the dorsal column system synapse specifically from the lower body and legs

odorant molecules.definition: volatile chemicals that bind to receptor proteins in olfactory neurons to stimulate the sense of smell

olfactory bulb.definition: central target of the first cranial nerve; located on the ventral surface of the frontal lobe in the cerebrum

olfactory epithelium.definition: region of the nasal epithelium where olfactory neurons are located

olfactory sensory neuron.definition: receptor cell of the olfactory system, sensitive to the chemical stimuli of smell, the axons of which compose the first cranial nerve

opsin.definition: protein that contains the photosensitive cofactor retinal for phototransduction

optic chiasm.definition: decussation point in the visual system at which medial retina fibers cross to the other side of the brain

optic disc.definition: spot on the retina at which RGC axons leave the eye and blood vessels of the inner retina pass

optic nerve.definition: second cranial nerve, which is responsible visual sensation

optic tract.definition: name for the fiber structure containing axons from the retina posterior to the optic chiasm representing their CNS location

organ of Corti.definition: structure in the cochlea in which hair cells transduce movements from sound waves into electrochemical signals

osmoreceptor.definition: receptor cell that senses differences in the concentrations of bodily fluids on the basis of osmotic pressure

ossicles.definition: three small bones in the middle ear

otolith.definition: layer of calcium carbonate crystals located on top of the otolithic membrane

otolithic membrane.definition: gelatinous substance in the utricle and saccule of the inner ear that contains calcium carbonate crystals and into which the stereocilia of hair cells are embedded

outer segment.definition: in the eye, the section of a photoreceptor that contains opsin molecules that transduce light stimuli

outer synaptic layer.definition: layer in the retina at which photoreceptors connect to bipolar cells

oval window.definition: membrane at the base of the cochlea where the stapes attaches, marking the beginning of the scala vestibuli

palpebral conjunctiva.definition: membrane attached to the inner surface of the eyelids that covers the anterior surface of the cornea

papilla.definition: for gustation, a bump-like projection on the surface of the tongue that contains taste buds

photoisomerization.definition: chemical change in the retinal molecule that alters the bonding so that it switches from the 11-cis-retinal isomer to the all-trans-retinal isomer

photoreceptor.definition: receptor cell specialized to respond to light stimuli

premotor cortex.definition: cortical area anterior to the primary motor cortex that is responsible for planning movements

primary sensory cortex.definition: region of the cerebral cortex that initially receives sensory input from an ascending pathway from the thalamus and begins the processing that will result in conscious perception of that modality

proprioception.definition: sense of position and movement of the body

proprioceptor.definition: receptor cell that senses changes in the position and kinesthetic aspects of the body

pupil.definition: open hole at the center of the iris that light passes through into the eye

pyramidal decussation.definition: location at which corticospinal tract fibers cross the midline and segregate into the anterior and lateral divisions of the pathway

pyramids.definition: segment of the descending motor pathway that travels in the anterior position of the medulla

receptor cell.definition: cell that transduces environmental stimuli into neural signals

red nucleus.definition: midbrain nucleus that sends corrective commands to the spinal cord along the rubrospinal tract, based on disparity between an original command and the sensory feedback from movement

reticulospinal tract.definition: extrapyramidal connections between the brain stem and spinal cord that modulate movement, contribute to posture, and regulate muscle tone

retina.definition: nervous tissue of the eye at which phototransduction takes place

retinal.definition: cofactor in an opsin molecule that undergoes a biochemical change when struck by a photon (pronounced with a stress on the last syllable)

retinal ganglion cell (RGC).definition: neuron of the retina that projects along the second cranial nerve

rhodopsin.definition: photopigment molecule found in the rod photoreceptors

rod photoreceptor.definition: one of the two types of retinal receptor cell that is specialized for low-light vision

round window.definition: membrane that marks the end of the scala tympani

rubrospinal tract.definition: descending motor control pathway, originating in the red nucleus, that mediates control of the limbs on the basis of cerebellar processing

saccule.definition: structure of the inner ear responsible for transducing linear acceleration in the vertical plane

scala tympani.definition: portion of the cochlea that extends from the apex to the round window

scala vestibuli.definition: portion of the cochlea that extends from the oval window to the apex

semicircular canals.definition: structures within the inner ear responsible for transducing rotational movement information

sensory homunculus.definition: topographic representation of the body within the somatosensory cortex demonstrating the correspondence between neurons processing stimuli and sensitivity

sensory modality.definition: a particular system for interpreting and perceiving environmental stimuli by the nervous system

solitary nucleus.definition: medullar nucleus that receives taste information from the facial and glossopharyngeal nerves

somatosensation.definition: general sense associated with modalities lumped together as touch

special sense.definition: any sensory system associated with a specific organ structure, namely smell, taste, sight, hearing, and balance

spinal trigeminal nucleus.definition: component of the trigeminal nuclei that is found in the medulla

spinothalamic tract.definition: ascending tract of the spinal cord associated with pain and temperature sensations

spiral ganglion.definition: location of neuronal cell bodies that transmit auditory information along the eighth cranial nerve

stapes.definition: (also, stirrup) ossicle of the middle ear that is attached to the inner ear

stereocilia.definition: array of apical membrane extensions in a hair cell that transduce movements when they are bent

stretch reflex.definition: response to activation of the muscle spindle stretch receptor that causes contraction of the muscle to maintain a constant length

submodality.definition: specific sense within a broader major sense such as sweet as a part of the sense of taste, or color as a part of vision

superior colliculus.definition: structure in the midbrain that combines visual, auditory, and somatosensory input to coordinate spatial and topographic representations of the three sensory systems

superior oblique.definition: extraocular muscle responsible for medial rotation of the eye

superior rectus.definition: extraocular muscle responsible for looking up

supplemental motor area.definition: cortical area anterior to the primary motor cortex that is responsible for planning movements

suprachiasmatic nucleus.definition: hypothalamic target of the retina that helps to establish the circadian rhythm of the body on the basis of the presence or absence of daylight

taste buds.definition: structures within a papilla on the tongue that contain gustatory receptor cells

tectorial membrane.definition: component of the organ of Corti that lays over the hair cells, into which the stereocilia are embedded

tectospinal tract.definition: extrapyramidal connections between the superior colliculus and spinal cord

thermoreceptor.definition: sensory receptor specialized for temperature stimuli

transduction.definition: process of changing an environmental stimulus into the electrochemical signals of the nervous system

trochlea.definition: cartilaginous structure that acts like a pulley for the superior oblique muscle

umami.definition: taste submodality for sensitivity to the concentration of amino acids; also called the savory sense

utricle.definition: structure of the inner ear responsible for transducing linear acceleration in the horizontal plane

vascular tunic.definition: middle layer of the eye primarily composed of connective tissue with a rich blood supply

ventral posterior nucleus.definition: nucleus in the thalamus that is the target of gustatory sensations and projects to the cerebral cortex

ventral stream.definition: connections between cortical areas from the occipital lobe to the temporal lobe that are responsible for identification of visual stimuli

vestibular ganglion.definition: location of neuronal cell bodies that transmit equilibrium information along the eighth cranial nerve

vestibular nuclei.definition: targets of the vestibular component of the eighth cranial nerve

vestibule.definition: in the ear, the portion of the inner ear responsible for the sense of equilibrium

vestibulo-ocular reflex (VOR).definition: reflex based on connections between the vestibular system and the cranial nerves of eye movements that ensures images are stabilized on the retina as the head and body move

vestibulospinal tract.definition: extrapyramidal connections between the vestibular nuclei in the brain stem and spinal cord that modulate movement and contribute to balance on the basis of the sense of equilibrium

visceral sense.definition: sense associated with the internal organs

vision.definition: special sense of sight based on transduction of light stimuli

visual acuity.definition: property of vision related to the sharpness of focus, which varies in relation to retinal position

vitreous humor.definition: viscous fluid that fills the posterior chamber of the eye

working memory.definition: function of the prefrontal cortex to maintain a representation of information that is not in the immediate environment

zonule fibers.definition: fibrous connections between the ciliary body and the lens

acetylcholine (ACh).definition: neurotransmitter that binds at a motor end-plate to trigger depolarization

adrenal medulla.definition: interior portion of the adrenal (or suprarenal) gland that releases epinephrine and norepinephrine into the bloodstream as hormones

adrenergic.definition: synapse where norepinephrine is released, which binds to Î±- or Î²-adrenergic receptors

afferent branch.definition: component of a reflex arc that represents the input from a sensory neuron, for either a special or general sense

agonist.definition: any exogenous substance that binds to a receptor and produces a similar effect to the endogenous ligand

alpha (\u00ce\u00b1)-adrenergic receptor.definition: one of the receptors to which epinephrine and norepinephrine bind, which comes in two subtypes: Î±1and Î±2

antagonist.definition: any exogenous substance that binds to a receptor and produces an opposing effect to the endogenous ligand

anticholinergic drugs.definition: drugs that interrupt or reduce the function of the parasympathetic system

autonomic tone.definition: tendency of an organ system to be governed by one division of the autonomic nervous system over the other, such as heart rate being lowered by parasympathetic input at rest

baroreceptor.definition: mechanoreceptor that senses the stretch of blood vessels to indicate changes in blood pressure

beta (\u00ce\u00b2)-adrenergic receptor.definition: one of the receptors to which epinephrine and norepinephrine bind, which comes in three subtypes: Î²1, Î²2, and Î²3

cardiac accelerator nerves.definition: preganglionic sympathetic fibers that cause the heart rate to increase when the cardiovascular center in the medulla initiates a signal

cardiovascular center.definition: region in the medulla that controls the cardiovascular system through cardiac accelerator nerves and vasomotor nerves, which are components of the sympathetic division of the autonomic nervous system

celiac ganglion.definition: one of the collateral ganglia of the sympathetic system that projects to the digestive system

central neuron.definition: specifically referring to the cell body of a neuron in the autonomic system that is located in the central nervous system, specifically the lateral horn of the spinal cord or a brain stem nucleus

cholinergic.definition: synapse at which acetylcholine is released and binds to the nicotinic or muscarinic receptor

chromaffin cells.definition: neuroendocrine cells of the adrenal medulla that release epinephrine and norepinephrine into the bloodstream as part of sympathetic system activity

ciliary ganglion.definition: one of the terminal ganglia of the parasympathetic system, located in the posterior orbit, axons from which project to the iris

collateral ganglia.definition: ganglia outside of the sympathetic chain that are targets of sympathetic preganglionic fibers, which are the celiac, inferior mesenteric, and superior mesenteric ganglia

craniosacral system.definition: alternate name for the parasympathetic division of the autonomic nervous system that is based on the anatomical location of central neurons in brain-stem nuclei and the lateral horn of the sacral spinal cord; also referred to as craniosacral outflow

dorsal longitudinal fasciculus.definition: major output pathway of the hypothalamus that descends through the gray matter of the brain stem and into the spinal cord

dorsal nucleus of the vagus nerve.definition: location of parasympathetic neurons that project through the vagus nerve to terminal ganglia in the thoracic and abdominal cavities

Edinger\u00e2\u0080\u0093Westphal nucleu.definition: location of parasympathetic neurons that project to the ciliary ganglion

efferent branch.definition: component of a reflex arc that represents the output, with the target being an effector, such as muscle or glandular tissue

endogenous.definition: describes substance made in the human body

endogenous chemical.definition: substance produced and released within the body to interact with a receptor protein

epinephrine.definition: signaling molecule released from the adrenal medulla into the bloodstream as part of the sympathetic response

exogenous.definition: describes substance made outside of the human body

exogenous chemical.definition: substance from a source outside the body, whether it be another organism such as a plant or from the synthetic processes of a laboratory, that binds to a transmembrane receptor protein

fight-or-flight response.definition: set of responses induced by sympathetic activity that lead to either fleeing a threat or standing up to it, which in the modern world is often associated with anxious feelings

G protein\u00e2\u0080\u0093coupled recep.definition: membrane protein complex that consists of a receptor protein that binds to a signaling moleculeâa G proteinâthat is activated by that binding and in turn activates an effector protein (enzyme) that creates a second-messenger molecule in the cytoplasm of the target cell

ganglionic neuron.definition: specifically refers to the cell body of a neuron in the autonomic system that is located in a ganglion

gray rami communicantes.definition: (singular = ramus communicans) unmyelinated structures that provide a short connection from a sympathetic chain ganglion to the spinal nerve that contains the postganglionic sympathetic fiber

greater splanchnic nerve.definition: nerve that contains fibers of the central sympathetic neurons that do not synapse in the chain ganglia but project onto the celiac ganglion

inferior mesenteric ganglion.definition: one of the collateral ganglia of the sympathetic system that projects to the digestive system

intramural ganglia.definition: terminal ganglia of the parasympathetic system that are found within the walls of the target effector

lesser splanchnic nerve.definition: nerve that contains fibers of the central sympathetic neurons that do not synapse in the chain ganglia but project onto the inferior mesenteric ganglion

ligand-gated cation channel.definition: ion channel, such as the nicotinic receptor, that is specific to positively charged ions and opens when a molecule such as a neurotransmitter binds to it

limbic lobe.definition: structures arranged around the edges of the cerebrum that are involved in memory and emotion

long reflex.definition: reflex arc that includes the central nervous system

medial forebrain bundle.definition: fiber pathway that extends anteriorly into the basal forebrain, passes through the hypothalamus, and extends into the brain stem and spinal cord

mesenteric plexus.definition: nervous tissue within the wall of the digestive tract that contains neurons that are the targets of autonomic preganglionic fibers and that project to the smooth muscle and glandular tissues in the digestive organ

muscarinic receptor.definition: type of acetylcholine receptor protein that is characterized by also binding to muscarine and is a metabotropic receptor

mydriasis.definition: dilation of the pupil; typically the result of disease, trauma, or drugs

nicotinic receptor.definition: type of acetylcholine receptor protein that is characterized by also binding to nicotine and is an ionotropic receptor

norepinephrine.definition: signaling molecule released as a neurotransmitter by most postganglionic sympathetic fibers as part of the sympathetic response, or as a hormone into the bloodstream from the adrenal medulla

nucleus ambiguus.definition: brain-stem nucleus that contains neurons that project through the vagus nerve to terminal ganglia in the thoracic cavity; specifically associated with the heart

parasympathetic division.definition: division of the autonomic nervous system responsible for restful and digestive functions

parasympathomimetic drugs.definition: drugs that enhance or mimic the function of the parasympathetic system

paravertebral ganglia.definition: autonomic ganglia superior to the sympathetic chain ganglia

postganglionic fiber.definition: axon from a ganglionic neuron in the autonomic nervous system that projects to and synapses with the target effector; sometimes referred to as a postganglionic neuron

preganglionic fiber.definition: axon from a central neuron in the autonomic nervous system that projects to and synapses with a ganglionic neuron; sometimes referred to as a preganglionic neuron

prevertebral ganglia.definition: autonomic ganglia that are anterior to the vertebral column and functionally related to the sympathetic chain ganglia

referred pain.definition: the conscious perception of visceral sensation projected to a different region of the body, such as the left shoulder and arm pain as a sign for a heart attack

reflex arc.definition: circuit of a reflex that involves a sensory input and motor output, or an afferent branch and an efferent branch, and an integrating center to connect the two branches

rest and digest.definition: set of functions associated with the parasympathetic system that lead to restful actions and digestion

short reflex.definition: reflex arc that does not include any components of the central nervous system

somatic reflex.definition: reflex involving skeletal muscle as the effector, under the control of the somatic nervous system

superior cervical ganglion.definition: one of the paravertebral ganglia of the sympathetic system that projects to the head

superior mesenteric ganglion.definition: one of the collateral ganglia of the sympathetic system that projects to the digestive system

sympathetic chain ganglia.definition: series of ganglia adjacent to the vertebral column that receive input from central sympathetic neurons

sympathetic division.definition: division of the autonomic nervous system associated with the fight-or-flight response

sympatholytic drug.definition: drug that interrupts, or âlyses,â the function of the sympathetic system

sympathomimetic drug.definition: drug that enhances or mimics the function of the sympathetic system

target effector.definition: organ, tissue, or gland that will respond to the control of an autonomic or somatic or endocrine signal

terminal ganglia.definition: ganglia of the parasympathetic division of the autonomic system, which are located near or within the target effector, the latter also known as intramural ganglia

thoracolumbar system.definition: alternate name for the sympathetic division of the autonomic nervous system that is based on the anatomical location of central neurons in the lateral horn of the thoracic and upper lumbar spinal cord

varicosity.definition: structure of some autonomic connections that is not a typical synaptic end bulb, but a string of swellings along the length of a fiber that makes a network of connections with the target effector

vasomotor nerves.definition: preganglionic sympathetic fibers that cause the constriction of blood vessels in response to signals from the cardiovascular center

visceral reflex.definition: reflex involving an internal organ as the effector, under the control of the autonomic nervous system

white rami communicantes.definition: (singular = ramus communicans) myelinated structures that provide a short connection from a sympathetic chain ganglion to the spinal nerve that contains the preganglionic sympathetic fiber

accommodation.definition: in vision, a change in the ability of the eye to focus on objects at different distances

accommodation\u00e2\u0080\u0093convergen.definition: coordination of somatic control of the medial rectus muscles of either eye with the parasympathetic control of the ciliary bodies to maintain focus while the eyes converge on visual stimuli near to the face

anterograde amnesia.definition: inability to form new memories from a particular time forward

ataxia.definition: movement disorder related to damage of the cerebellum characterized by loss of coordination in voluntary movements

Babinski sign.definition: dorsiflexion of the foot with extension and splaying of the toes in response to the plantar reflex, normally suppressed by corticospinal input

cerebrocerebellum.definition: lateral regions of the cerebellum; named for the significant input from the cerebral cortex

check reflex.definition: response to a release in resistance so that the contractions stop, or check, movement

clasp-knife response.definition: sign of UMN disease when a patient initially resists passive movement of a muscle but will quickly release to a lower state of resistance

conduction aphasia.definition: loss of language function related to connecting the understanding of speech with the production of speech, without either specific function being lost

conductive hearing.definition: hearing dependent on the conduction of vibrations of the tympanic membrane through the ossicles of the middle ear

conjugate gaze.definition: coordinated movement of the two eyes simultaneously in the same direction

convergence.definition: in vision, the movement of the eyes so that they are both pointed at the same point in space, which increases for stimuli that are closer to the subject

coordination exam.definition: major section of the neurological exam that assesses complex, coordinated motor functions of the cerebellum and associated motor pathways

cortico-ponto-cerebellar pathway.definition: projection from the cerebral cortex to the cerebellum by way of the gray matter of the pons

cranial nerve exam.definition: major section of the neurological exam that assesses sensory and motor functions of the cranial nerves and their associated central and peripheral structures

cytoarchitecture.definition: study of a tissue based on the structure and organization of its cellular components; related to the broader term, histology

deep tendon reflex.definition: another term for stretch reflex, based on the elicitation through deep stimulation of the tendon at the insertion

diplopia.definition: double vision resulting from a failure in conjugate gaze

edema.definition: fluid accumulation in tissue; often associated with circulatory deficits

embolus.definition: obstruction in a blood vessel such as a blood clot, fatty mass, air bubble, or other foreign matter that interrupts the flow of blood to an organ or some part of the body

episodic memory.definition: memory of specific events in an autobiographical sense

expressive aphasia.definition: loss of the ability to produce language; usually associated with damage to Brocaâs area in the frontal lobe

extrinsic muscles of the tongue.definition: muscles that are connected to other structures, such as the hyoid bone or the mandible, and control the position of the tongue

fasciculation.definition: small muscle twitch as a result of spontaneous activity from an LMN

fauces.definition: opening from the oral cavity into the pharynx

fibrillation.definition: in motor responses, a spontaneous muscle action potential that occurs in the absence of neuromuscular input, resulting from LMN lesions

flaccid paralysis.definition: loss of voluntary muscle control and muscle tone, as the result of LMN disease

flaccidity.definition: presentation of a loss of muscle tone, observed as floppy limbs or a lack of resistance to passive movement

flocculonodular lobe.definition: lobe of the cerebellum that receives input from the vestibular system to help with balance and posture

gait.definition: rhythmic pattern of alternating movements of the lower limbs during locomotion

gait exam.definition: major section of the neurological exam that assesses the cerebellum and descending pathways in the spinal cord through the coordinated motor functions of walking; a portion of the coordination exam

gnosis.definition: in a neurological exam, intuitive experiential knowledge tested by interacting with common objects or symbols

graphesthesia.definition: perception of symbols, such as letters or numbers, traced in the palm of the hand

hemisection.definition: cut through half of a structure, such as the spinal cord

hemorrhagic stroke.definition: disruption of blood flow to the brain caused by bleeding within the cranial vault

hypotonicity.definition: low muscle tone, a sign of LMN disease

inferior cerebellar peduncle (ICP).definition: input to the cerebellum, largely from the inferior olive, that represents sensory feedback from the periphery

inferior olive.definition: large nucleus in the medulla that receives input from sensory systems and projects into the cerebellar cortex

internuclear ophthalmoplegia.definition: deficit of conjugate lateral gaze because the lateral rectus muscle of one eye does not contract resulting from damage to the abducens nerve or the MLF

intorsion.definition: medial rotation of the eye around its axis

intrinsic muscles of the tongue.definition: muscles that originate out of, and insert into, other tissues within the tongue and control the shape of the tongue

ischemic stroke.definition: disruption of blood flow to the brain because blood cannot flow through blood vessels as a result of a blockage or narrowing of the vessel

jaw-jerk reflex.definition: stretch reflex of the masseter muscle

localization of function.definition: principle that circumscribed anatomical locations are responsible for specific functions in an organ system

medial longitudinal fasciculus (MLF).definition: fiber pathway that connects structures involved in the control of eye and head position, from the superior colliculus to the vestibular nuclei and cerebellum

mental status exam.definition: major section of the neurological exam that assesses cognitive functions of the cerebrum

middle cerebellar peduncle (MCP).definition: large, white-matter bridge from the pons that constitutes the major input to the cerebellar cortex

motor exam.definition: major section of the neurological exam that assesses motor functions of the spinal cord and spinal nerves

neurological exam.definition: clinical assessment tool that can be used to quickly evaluate neurological function and determine if specific parts of the nervous system have been affected by damage or disease

paramedian pontine reticular formation (.definition: region of the brain stem adjacent to the motor nuclei for gaze control that coordinates rapid, conjugate eye movements

paresis.definition: partial loss of, or impaired, voluntary muscle control

plantar reflex.definition: superficial reflex initiated by gentle stimulation of the sole of the foot

praxis.definition: in a neurological exam, the act of doing something using ready knowledge or skills in response to verbal instruction

procedural memory.definition: memory of how to perform a specific task

pronator drift.definition: sign of contralateral corticospinal lesion when the one arm will drift into a pronated position when held straight out with the palms facing upward

receptive aphasia.definition: loss of the ability to understand received language, such as what is spoken to the subject or given in written form

red nucleus.definition: nucleus in the midbrain that receives output from the cerebellum and projects onto the spinal cord in the rubrospinal tract

retrograde amnesia.definition: loss of memories before a particular event

Rinne test.definition: use of a tuning fork to test conductive hearing loss versus sensorineural hearing loss

Romberg test.definition: test of equilibrium that requires the patient to maintain a straight, upright posture without visual feedback of position

rubrospinal tract.definition: descending tract from the red nucleus of the midbrain that results in modification of ongoing motor programs

saccade.definition: small, rapid movement of the eyes used to locate and direct the fovea onto visual stimuli

sensorineural hearing.definition: hearing dependent on the transduction and propagation of auditory information through the neural components of the peripheral auditory structures

sensory exam.definition: major section of the neurological exam that assesses sensory functions of the spinal cord and spinal nerves

short-term memory.definition: capacity to retain information actively in the brain for a brief period of time

Snellen chart.definition: standardized arrangement of letters in decreasing size presented to a subject at a distance of 20 feet to test visual acuity

spasticity.definition: increased contraction of a muscle in response to resistance, often resulting in hyperflexia

spinocerebellar tract.definition: ascending fibers that carry proprioceptive input to the cerebellum used in maintaining balance and coordinated movement

spinocerebellum.definition: midline region of the cerebellum known as the vermis that receives proprioceptive input from the spinal cord

stereognosis.definition: perception of common objects placed in the hand solely on the basis of manipulation of that object in the hand

stroke.definition: (also, cerebrovascular accident (CVA)) loss of neurological function caused by an interruption of blood flow to a region of the central nervous system

superficial reflex.definition: reflexive contraction initiated by gentle stimulation of the skin

superior cerebellar peduncle (SCP).definition: white-matter tract representing output of the cerebellum to the red nucleus of the midbrain

transient ischemic attack (TIA).definition: temporary disruption of blood flow to the brain in which symptoms occur rapidly but last only a short time

vermis.definition: prominent ridge along the midline of the cerebellum that is referred to as the spinocerebellum

vestibulo-ocular reflex (VOR).definition: reflex based on connections between the vestibular system and the cranial nerves of eye movements that ensures that images are stabilized on the retina as the head and body move

vestibulocerebellum.definition: flocculonodular lobe of the cerebellum named for the vestibular input from the eighth cranial nerve

Weber test.definition: use of a tuning fork to test the laterality of hearing loss by placing it at several locations on the midline of the skull

Wernicke\u00e2\u0080\u0099s area.definition: region at the posterior end of the lateral sulcus in which speech comprehension is localized

acromegaly.definition: disorder in adults caused when abnormally high levels of GH trigger growth of bones in the face, hands, and feet

adenylyl cyclase.definition: membrane-bound enzyme that converts ATP to cyclic AMP, creating cAMP, as a result of G-protein activation

adrenal cortex.definition: outer region of the adrenal glands consisting of multiple layers of epithelial cells and capillary networks that produces mineralocorticoids and glucocorticoids

adrenal glands.definition: endocrine glands located at the top of each kidney that are important for the regulation of the stress response, blood pressure and blood volume, water homeostasis, and electrolyte levels

adrenal medulla.definition: inner layer of the adrenal glands that plays an important role in the stress response by producing epinephrine and norepinephrine

adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH).definition: anterior pituitary hormone that stimulates the adrenal cortex to secrete corticosteroid hormones (also called corticotropin)

alarm reaction.definition: the short-term stress, or the fight-or-flight response, of stage one of the general adaptation syndrome mediated by the hormones epinephrine and norepinephrine

aldosterone.definition: hormone produced and secreted by the adrenal cortex that stimulates sodium and fluid retention and increases blood volume and blood pressure

alpha cell.definition: pancreatic islet cell type that produces the hormone glucagon

angiotensin-converting enzyme.definition: the enzyme that converts angiotensin I to angiotensin II

antidiuretic hormone (ADH).definition: hypothalamic hormone that is stored by the posterior pituitary and that signals the kidneys to reabsorb water

atrial natriuretic peptide (ANP).definition: peptide hormone produced by the walls of the atria in response to high blood pressure, blood volume, or blood sodium that reduces the reabsorption of sodium and water in the kidneys and promotes vasodilation

autocrine.definition: chemical signal that elicits a response in the same cell that secreted it

beta cell.definition: pancreatic islet cell type that produces the hormone insulin

calcitonin.definition: peptide hormone produced and secreted by the parafollicular cells (C cells) of the thyroid gland that functions to decrease blood calcium levels

chromaffin.definition: neuroendocrine cells of the adrenal medulla

colloid.definition: viscous fluid in the central cavity of thyroid follicles, containing the glycoprotein thyroglobulin

cortisol.definition: glucocorticoid important in gluconeogenesis, the catabolism of glycogen, and downregulation of the immune system

cyclic adenosine monophosphate (cAMP).definition: second messenger that, in response to adenylyl cyclase activation, triggers a phosphorylation cascade

delta cell.definition: minor cell type in the pancreas that secretes the hormone somatostatin

diabetes mellitus.definition: condition caused by destruction or dysfunction of the beta cells of the pancreas or cellular resistance to insulin that results in abnormally high blood glucose levels

diacylglycerol (DAG).definition: molecule that, like cAMP, activates protein kinases, thereby initiating a phosphorylation cascade

downregulation.definition: decrease in the number of hormone receptors, typically in response to chronically excessive levels of a hormone

endocrine gland.definition: tissue or organ that secretes hormones into the blood and lymph without ducts such that they may be transported to organs distant from the site of secretion

endocrine system.definition: cells, tissues, and organs that secrete hormones as a primary or secondary function and play an integral role in normal bodily processes

epinephrine.definition: primary and most potent catecholamine hormone secreted by the adrenal medulla in response to short-term stress; also called adrenaline

erythropoietin (EPO).definition: protein hormone secreted in response to low oxygen levels that triggers the bone marrow to produce red blood cells

estrogens.definition: class of predominantly female sex hormones important for the development and growth of the female reproductive tract, secondary sex characteristics, the female reproductive cycle, and the maintenance of pregnancy

exocrine system.definition: cells, tissues, and organs that secrete substances directly to target tissues via glandular ducts

first messenger.definition: hormone that binds to a cell membrane hormone receptor and triggers activation of a second messenger system

follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH).definition: anterior pituitary hormone that stimulates the production and maturation of sex cells

G protein.definition: protein associated with a cell membrane hormone receptor that initiates the next step in a second messenger system upon activation by hormoneâreceptor binding

general adaptation syndrome (GAS).definition: the human bodyâs three-stage response pattern to short- and long-term stress

gigantism.definition: disorder in children caused when abnormally high levels of GH prompt excessive growth

glucagon.definition: pancreatic hormone that stimulates the catabolism of glycogen to glucose, thereby increasing blood glucose levels

glucocorticoids.definition: hormones produced by the zona fasciculata of the adrenal cortex that influence glucose metabolism

goiter.definition: enlargement of the thyroid gland either as a result of iodine deficiency or hyperthyroidism

gonadotropins.definition: hormones that regulate the function of the gonads

growth hormone (GH).definition: anterior pituitary hormone that promotes tissue building and influences nutrient metabolism (also called somatotropin)

hormone.definition: secretion of an endocrine organ that travels via the bloodstream or lymphatics to induce a response in target cells or tissues in another part of the body

hormone receptor.definition: protein within a cell or on the cell membrane that binds a hormone, initiating the target cell response

hyperparathyroidism.definition: disorder caused by overproduction of PTH that results in abnormally elevated blood calcium

hyperthyroidism.definition: clinically abnormal, elevated level of thyroid hormone in the blood; characterized by an increased metabolic rate, excess body heat, sweating, diarrhea, weight loss, and increased heart rate

hypoparathyroidism.definition: disorder caused by underproduction of PTH that results in abnormally low blood calcium

hypophyseal portal system.definition: network of blood vessels that enables hypothalamic hormones to travel into the anterior lobe of the pituitary without entering the systemic circulation

hypothalamus.definition: region of the diencephalon inferior to the thalamus that functions in neural and endocrine signaling

hypothyroidism.definition: clinically abnormal, low level of thyroid hormone in the blood; characterized by low metabolic rate, weight gain, cold extremities, constipation, and reduced mental activity

infundibulum.definition: stalk containing vasculature and neural tissue that connects the pituitary gland to the hypothalamus (also called the pituitary stalk)

inhibin.definition: hormone secreted by the male and female gonads that inhibits FSH production by the anterior pituitary

inositol triphosphate (IP3).definition: molecule that initiates the release of calcium ions from intracellular stores

insulin.definition: pancreatic hormone that enhances the cellular uptake and utilization of glucose, thereby decreasing blood glucose levels

insulin-like growth factors (IGF).definition: protein that enhances cellular proliferation, inhibits apoptosis, and stimulates the cellular uptake of amino acids for protein synthesis

leptin.definition: protein hormone secreted by adipose tissues in response to food consumption that promotes satiety

luteinizing hormone (LH).definition: anterior pituitary hormone that triggers ovulation and the production of ovarian hormones, and the production of testosterone

melatonin.definition: amino acidâderived hormone that is secreted in response to low light and causes drowsiness

mineralocorticoids.definition: hormones produced by the zona glomerulosa cells of the adrenal cortex that influence fluid and electrolyte balance

neonatal hypothyroidism.definition: condition characterized by cognitive deficits, short stature, and other signs and symptoms in people born to people who were iodine-deficient during pregnancy

norepinephrine.definition: secondary catecholamine hormone secreted by the adrenal medulla in response to short-term stress; also called noradrenaline

osmoreceptor.definition: hypothalamic sensory receptor that is stimulated by changes in solute concentration (osmotic pressure) in the blood

oxytocin.definition: hypothalamic hormone stored in the posterior pituitary gland and important in stimulating uterine contractions in labor, milk ejection during breastfeeding, and feelings of attachment (produced by males and females)

pancreas.definition: organ with both exocrine and endocrine functions located posterior to the stomach that is important for digestion and the regulation of blood glucose

pancreatic islets.definition: specialized clusters of pancreatic cells that have endocrine functions; also called islets of Langerhans

paracrine.definition: chemical signal that elicits a response in neighboring cells; also called paracrine factor

parathyroid glands.definition: small, round glands embedded in the posterior thyroid gland that produce parathyroid hormone (PTH)

parathyroid hormone (PTH).definition: peptide hormone produced and secreted by the parathyroid glands in response to low blood calcium levels

phosphodiesterase (PDE).definition: cytosolic enzyme that deactivates and degrades cAMP

phosphorylation cascade.definition: signaling event in which multiple protein kinases phosphorylate the next protein substrate by transferring a phosphate group from ATP to the protein

pineal gland.definition: endocrine gland that secretes melatonin, which is important in regulating the sleep-wake cycle

pinealocyte.definition: cell of the pineal gland that produces and secretes the hormone melatonin

pituitary dwarfism.definition: disorder in children caused when abnormally low levels of GH result in growth retardation

pituitary gland.definition: bean-sized organ suspended from the hypothalamus that produces, stores, and secretes hormones in response to hypothalamic stimulation (also called hypophysis)

PP cell.definition: minor cell type in the pancreas that secretes the hormone pancreatic polypeptide

progesterone.definition: predominantly female sex hormone important in regulating the female reproductive cycle and the maintenance of pregnancy

prolactin (PRL).definition: anterior pituitary hormone that promotes development of the mammary glands and the production of breast milk

protein kinase.definition: enzyme that initiates a phosphorylation cascade upon activation

second messenger.definition: molecule that initiates a signaling cascade in response to hormone binding on a cell membrane receptor and activation of a G protein

stage of exhaustion.definition: stage three of the general adaptation syndrome; the bodyâs long-term response to stress mediated by the hormones of the adrenal cortex

stage of resistance.definition: stage two of the general adaptation syndrome; the bodyâs continued response to stress after stage one diminishes

testosterone.definition: steroid hormone secreted by the testes and important in the maturation of sperm cells, growth and development of the reproductive system, and the development of secondary sex characteristics

thymosins.definition: hormones produced and secreted by the thymus that play an important role in the development and differentiation of T cells

thymus.definition: organ that is involved in the development and maturation of T-cells and is particularly active during infancy and childhood

thyroid gland.definition: large endocrine gland responsible for the synthesis of thyroid hormones

thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH).definition: anterior pituitary hormone that triggers secretion of thyroid hormones by the thyroid gland (also called thyrotropin)

thyroxine.definition: (also, tetraiodothyronine, T4) amino acidâderived thyroid hormone that is more abundant but less potent than T3and often converted to T3by target cells

triiodothyronine.definition: (also, T3) amino acidâderived thyroid hormone that is less abundant but more potent than T4

upregulation.definition: increase in the number of hormone receptors, typically in response to chronically reduced levels of a hormone

zona fasciculata.definition: intermediate region of the adrenal cortex that produce hormones called glucocorticoids

zona glomerulosa.definition: most superficial region of the adrenal cortex, which produces the hormones collectively referred to as mineralocorticoids

zona reticularis.definition: deepest region of the adrenal cortex, which produces the steroid sex hormones called androgens

ABO blood group.definition: blood-type classification based on the presence or absence of A and B glycoproteins on the erythrocyte membrane surface

agglutination.definition: clustering of cells into masses linked by antibodies

agranular leukocytes.definition: leukocytes with few granules in their cytoplasm; specifically, monocytes, lymphocytes, and NK cells

albumin.definition: most abundant plasma protein, accounting for most of the osmotic pressure of plasma

anemia.definition: deficiency of red blood cells or hemoglobin

antibodies.definition: (also, immunoglobulins or gamma globulins) antigen-specific proteins produced by specialized B lymphocytes that protect the body by binding to foreign objects such as bacteria and viruses

anticoagulant.definition: substance such as heparin that opposes coagulation

antithrombin.definition: anticoagulant that inactivates factor X and opposes the conversion of prothrombin (factor II) into thrombin in the common pathway

B lymphocytes.definition: (also, B cells) lymphocytes that defend the body against specific pathogens and thereby provide specific immunity

basophils.definition: granulocytes that stain with a basic (alkaline) stain and store histamine and heparin

bilirubin.definition: yellowish bile pigment produced when iron is removed from heme and is further broken down into waste products

biliverdin.definition: green bile pigment produced when the non-iron portion of heme is degraded into a waste product; converted to bilirubin in the liver

blood.definition: liquid connective tissue composed of formed elementsâerythrocytes, leukocytes, and plateletsâand a fluid extracellular matrix called plasma; component of the cardiovascular system

bone marrow biopsy.definition: diagnostic test of a sample of red bone marrow

bone marrow transplant.definition: treatment in which a donorâs healthy bone marrow with its stem cells replaces diseased or damaged bone marrow of a patient

bruise.definition: localized bleeding under the skin due to damaged blood vessels

buffy coat.definition: thin, pale layer of leukocytes and platelets that separates the erythrocytes from the plasma in a sample of centrifuged blood

carbaminohemoglobin.definition: compound of carbon dioxide and hemoglobin, and one of the ways in which carbon dioxide is carried in the blood

clotting factors.definition: group of 12 identified substances active in coagulation

coagulation.definition: formation of a blood clot; part of the process of hemostasis

colony-stimulating factors (CSFs).definition: glycoproteins that trigger the proliferation and differentiation of myeloblasts into granular leukocytes (basophils, neutrophils, and eosinophils)

common pathway.definition: final coagulation pathway activated either by the intrinsic or the extrinsic pathway, and ending in the formation of a blood clot

cross matching.definition: blood test for identification of blood type using antibodies and small samples of blood

cytokines.definition: class of proteins that act as autocrine or paracrine signaling molecules; in the cardiovascular system, they stimulate the proliferation of progenitor cells and help to stimulate both nonspecific and specific resistance to disease

defensins.definition: antimicrobial proteins released from neutrophils and macrophages that create openings in the plasma membranes to kill cells

deoxyhemoglobin.definition: molecule of hemoglobin without an oxygen molecule bound to it

diapedesis.definition: (also, emigration) process by which leukocytes squeeze through adjacent cells in a blood vessel wall to enter tissues

embolus.definition: thrombus that has broken free from the blood vessel wall and entered the circulation

emigration.definition: (also, diapedesis) process by which leukocytes squeeze through adjacent cells in a blood vessel wall to enter tissues

eosinophils.definition: granulocytes that stain with eosin; they release antihistamines and are especially active against parasitic worms

erythrocyte.definition: (also, red blood cell) mature myeloid blood cell that is composed mostly of hemoglobin and functions primarily in the transportation of oxygen and carbon dioxide

erythropoietin (EPO).definition: glycoprotein that triggers the bone marrow to produce RBCs; secreted by the kidney in response to low oxygen levels

extrinsic pathway.definition: initial coagulation pathway that begins with tissue damage and results in the activation of the common pathway

ferritin.definition: protein-containing storage form of iron found in the bone marrow, liver, and spleen

fibrin.definition: insoluble, filamentous protein that forms the structure of a blood clot

fibrinogen.definition: plasma protein produced in the liver and involved in blood clotting

fibrinolysis.definition: gradual degradation of a blood clot

formed elements.definition: cellular components of blood; that is, erythrocytes, leukocytes, and platelets

globin.definition: heme-containing globular protein that is a constituent of hemoglobin

globulins.definition: heterogeneous group of plasma proteins that includes transport proteins, clotting factors, immune proteins, and others

granular leukocytes.definition: leukocytes with abundant granules in their cytoplasm; specifically, neutrophils, eosinophils, and basophils

hematocrit.definition: (also, packed cell volume) volume percentage of erythrocytes in a sample of centrifuged blood

hematopoietic stem cell.definition: type of pluripotent stem cell that gives rise to the formed elements of blood (hemocytoblast)

heme.definition: red, iron-containing pigment to which oxygen binds in hemoglobin

hemocytoblast.definition: hematopoietic stem cell that gives rise to the formed elements of blood

hemolysis.definition: destruction (lysis) of erythrocytes and the release of their hemoglobin into circulation

hemolytic disease of the newborn (HDN).definition: (also, erythroblastosis fetalis) disorder causing agglutination and hemolysis in an Rh+fetus or newborn of an Rhâperson

hemophilia.definition: genetic disorder characterized by inadequate synthesis of clotting factors

hemopoiesis.definition: production of the formed elements of blood

hemopoietic growth factors.definition: chemical signals including erythropoietin, thrombopoietin, colony-stimulating factors, and interleukins that regulate the differentiation and proliferation of particular blood progenitor cells

hemosiderin.definition: protein-containing storage form of iron found in the bone marrow, liver, and spleen

hemostasis.definition: physiological process by which bleeding ceases

heparin.definition: short-acting anticoagulant stored in mast cells and released when tissues are injured, opposes prothrombin

hypoxemia.definition: below-normal level of oxygen saturation of blood (typically <95 percent)

immunoglobulins.definition: (also, antibodies or gamma globulins) antigen-specific proteins produced by specialized B lymphocytes that protect the body by binding to foreign objects such as bacteria and viruses

interleukins.definition: signaling molecules that may function in hemopoiesis, inflammation, and specific immune responses

intrinsic pathway.definition: initial coagulation pathway that begins with vascular damage or contact with foreign substances, and results in the activation of the common pathway

jaundice.definition: yellowing of the skin or whites of the eyes due to excess bilirubin in the blood

leukocyte.definition: (also, white blood cell) colorless, nucleated blood cell, the chief function of which is to protect the body from disease

lymphocytes.definition: agranular leukocytes of the lymphoid stem cell line, many of which function in specific immunity

lymphoid stem cells.definition: type of hematopoietic stem cells that gives rise to lymphocytes, including various T cells, B cells, and NK cells, all of which function in immunity

lymphoma.definition: form of cancer in which masses of malignant T and/or B lymphocytes collect in lymph nodes, the spleen, the liver, and other tissues

macrophage.definition: phagocytic cell of the myeloid lineage; a matured monocyte

megakaryocyte.definition: bone marrow cell that produces platelets

memory cell.definition: type of B or T lymphocyte that forms after exposure to a pathogen

monocytes.definition: agranular leukocytes of the myeloid stem cell line that circulate in the bloodstream; tissue monocytes are macrophages

myeloid stem cells.definition: type of hematopoietic stem cell that gives rise to some formed elements, including erythrocytes, megakaryocytes that produce platelets, and a myeloblast lineage that gives rise to monocytes and three forms of granular leukocytes (neutrophils, eosinophils, and basophils)

natural killer (NK) cells.definition: cytotoxic lymphocytes capable of recognizing cells that do not express âselfâ proteins on their plasma membrane or that contain foreign or abnormal markers; provide generalized, nonspecific immunity

neutrophils.definition: granulocytes that stain with a neutral dye and are the most numerous of the leukocytes; especially active against bacteria

oxyhemoglobin.definition: molecule of hemoglobin to which oxygen is bound

packed cell volume (PCV).definition: (also, hematocrit) volume percentage of erythrocytes present in a sample of centrifuged blood

plasma.definition: in blood, the liquid extracellular matrix composed mostly of water that circulates the formed elements and dissolved materials throughout the cardiovascular system

platelet plug.definition: accumulation and adhesion of platelets at the site of blood vessel injury

platelets.definition: (also, thrombocytes) one of the formed elements of blood that consists of cell fragments broken off from megakaryocytes

pluripotent stem cell.definition: stem cell that derives from totipotent stem cells and is capable of differentiating into many, but not all, cell types

polycythemia.definition: elevated level of hemoglobin, whether adaptive or pathological

polymorphonuclear.definition: having a lobed nucleus, as seen in some leukocytes

positive chemotaxis.definition: process in which a cell is attracted to move in the direction of chemical stimuli

red blood cells (RBCs).definition: (also, erythrocytes) one of the formed elements of blood that transports oxygen

reticulocyte.definition: immature erythrocyte that may still contain fragments of organelles

Rh blood group.definition: blood-type classification based on the presence or absence of the antigen Rh on the erythrocyte membrane surface

serum.definition: blood plasma that does not contain clotting factors

sickle cell disease.definition: (also, sickle cell anemia) inherited blood disorder in which hemoglobin molecules are malformed, leading to the breakdown of RBCs that take on a characteristic sickle shape

T lymphocytes.definition: (also, T cells) lymphocytes that provide cellular-level immunity by physically attacking foreign or diseased cells

thalassemia.definition: inherited blood disorder in which maturation of RBCs does not proceed normally, leading to abnormal formation of hemoglobin and the destruction of RBCs

thrombin.definition: enzyme essential for the final steps in formation of a fibrin clot

thrombocytes.definition: platelets, one of the formed elements of blood that consists of cell fragments broken off from megakaryocytes

thrombocytopenia.definition: condition in which there are too few platelets, resulting in abnormal bleeding (hemophilia)

thrombocytosis.definition: condition in which there are too many platelets, resulting in abnormal clotting (thrombosis)

thrombopoietin.definition: hormone secreted by the liver and kidneys that prompts the development of megakaryocytes into thrombocytes (platelets)

thrombus.definition: aggregation of fibrin, platelets, and erythrocytes in an intact artery or vein

tissue factor.definition: protein thromboplastin, which initiates the extrinsic pathway when released in response to tissue damage

totipotent stem cell.definition: embryonic stem cell that is capable of differentiating into any and all cells of the body; enabling the full development of an organism

transferrin.definition: plasma protein that binds reversibly to iron and distributes it throughout the body

vascular spasm.definition: initial step in hemostasis, in which the smooth muscle in the walls of the ruptured or damaged blood vessel contracts

white blood cells (WBCs).definition: (also, leukocytes) one of the formed elements of blood that provides defense against disease agents and foreign materials

afterload.definition: force the ventricles must develop to effectively pump blood against the resistance in the vessels

anastomosis.definition: (plural = anastomoses) area where vessels unite to allow blood to circulate even if there may be partial blockage in another branch

anterior cardiac veins.definition: vessels that parallel the small cardiac arteries and drain the anterior surface of the right ventricle; bypass the coronary sinus and drain directly into the right atrium

anterior interventricular artery.definition: (also, left anterior descending artery or LAD) major branch of the left coronary artery that follows the anterior interventricular sulcus

anterior interventricular sulcus.definition: sulcus located between the left and right ventricles on the anterior surface of the heart

aortic valve.definition: (also, aortic semilunar valve) valve located at the base of the aorta

artificial pacemaker.definition: medical device that transmits electrical signals to the heart to ensure that it contracts and pumps blood to the body

atrial reflex.definition: (also, called Bainbridge reflex) autonomic reflex that responds to stretch receptors in the atria that send impulses to the cardioaccelerator area to increase HR when venous flow into the atria increases

atrioventricular (AV) node.definition: clump of myocardial cells located in the inferior portion of the right atrium within the atrioventricular septum; receives the impulse from the SA node, pauses, and then transmits it into specialized conducting cells within the interventricular septum

atrioventricular bundle.definition: (also, bundle of His) group of specialized myocardial conductile cells that transmit the impulse from the AV node through the interventricular septum; form the left and right atrioventricular bundle branches

atrioventricular bundle branches.definition: (also, left or right bundle branches) specialized myocardial conductile cells that arise from the bifurcation of the atrioventricular bundle and pass through the interventricular septum; lead to the Purkinje fibers and also to the right papillary muscle via the moderator band

atrioventricular septum.definition: cardiac septum located between the atria and ventricles; atrioventricular valves are located here

atrioventricular valves.definition: one-way valves located between the atria and ventricles; the valve on the right is called the tricuspid valve, and the one on the left is the mitral or bicuspid valve

atrium.definition: (plural = atria) upper or receiving chamber of the heart that pumps blood into the lower chambers just prior to their contraction; the right atrium receives blood from the systemic circuit that flows into the right ventricle; the left atrium receives blood from the pulmonary circuit that flows into the left ventricle

auricle.definition: extension of an atrium visible on the superior surface of the heart

autonomic tone.definition: contractile state during resting cardiac activity produced by mild sympathetic and parasympathetic stimulation

autorhythmicity.definition: ability of cardiac muscle to initiate its own electrical impulse that triggers the mechanical contraction that pumps blood at a fixed pace without nervous or endocrine control

Bachmann\u00e2\u0080\u0099s bundle.definition: (also, interatrial band) group of specialized conducting cells that transmit the impulse directly from the SA node in the right atrium to the left atrium

Bainbridge reflex.definition: (also, called atrial reflex) autonomic reflex that responds to stretch receptors in the atria that send impulses to the cardioaccelerator area to increase HR when venous flow into the atria increases

baroreceptor reflex.definition: autonomic reflex in which the cardiac centers monitor signals from the baroreceptor stretch receptors and regulate heart function based on blood flow

bicuspid valve.definition: (also, mitral valve or left atrioventricular valve) valve located between the left atrium and ventricle; consists of two flaps of tissue

bulbus cordis.definition: portion of the primitive heart tube that will eventually develop into the right ventricle

bundle of His.definition: (also, atrioventricular bundle) group of specialized myocardial conductile cells that transmit the impulse from the AV node through the interventricular septum; form the left and right atrioventricular bundle branches

cardiac cycle.definition: period of time between the onset of atrial contraction (atrial systole) and ventricular relaxation (ventricular diastole)

cardiac notch.definition: depression in the medial surface of the superior lobe of the left lung where the apex of the heart is located

cardiac output (CO).definition: amount of blood pumped by each ventricle during one minute; equals HR multiplied by SV

cardiac plexus.definition: paired complex network of nerve fibers near the base of the heart that receive sympathetic and parasympathetic stimulations to regulate HR

cardiac reflexes.definition: series of autonomic reflexes that enable the cardiovascular centers to regulate heart function based upon sensory information from a variety of visceral sensors

cardiac reserve.definition: difference between maximum and resting CO

cardiac skeleton.definition: (also, skeleton of the heart) reinforced connective tissue located within the atrioventricular septum; includes four rings that surround the openings between the atria and ventricles, and the openings to the pulmonary trunk and aorta; the point of attachment for the heart valves

cardiogenic area.definition: area near the head of the embryo where the heart begins to develop 18â19 days after fertilization

cardiogenic cords.definition: two strands of tissue that form within the cardiogenic area

chordae tendineae.definition: string-like extensions of tough connective tissue that extend from the flaps of the atrioventricular valves to the papillary muscles

circumflex artery.definition: branch of the left coronary artery that follows coronary sulcus

coronary arteries.definition: branches of the ascending aorta that supply blood to the heart; the left coronary artery feeds the left side of the heart, the left atrium and ventricle, and the interventricular septum; the right coronary artery feeds the right atrium, portions of both ventricles, and the heart conduction system

coronary sinus.definition: large, thin-walled vein on the posterior surface of the heart that lies within the atrioventricular sulcus and drains the heart myocardium directly into the right atrium

coronary sulcus.definition: sulcus that marks the boundary between the atria and ventricles

coronary veins.definition: vessels that drain the heart and generally parallel the large surface arteries

diastole.definition: period of time when the heart muscle is relaxed and the chambers fill with blood

ejection fraction.definition: portion of the blood that is pumped or ejected from the heart with each contraction; mathematically represented by SV divided by EDV

electrocardiogram (ECG).definition: surface recording of the electrical activity of the heart that can be used for diagnosis of irregular heart function; also abbreviated as EKG

end diastolic volume (EDV).definition: (also, preload) the amount of blood in the ventricles at the end of atrial systole just prior to ventricular contraction

end systolic volume (ESV).definition: amount of blood remaining in each ventricle following systole

endocardial tubes.definition: stage in which lumens form within the expanding cardiogenic cords, forming hollow structures

endocardium.definition: innermost layer of the heart lining the heart chambers and heart valves; composed of endothelium reinforced with a thin layer of connective tissue that binds to the myocardium

endothelium.definition: layer of smooth, simple squamous epithelium that lines the endocardium and blood vessels

epicardial coronary arteries.definition: surface arteries of the heart that generally follow the sulci

epicardium.definition: innermost layer of the serous pericardium and the outermost layer of the heart wall

filling time.definition: duration of ventricular diastole during which filling occurs

foramen ovale.definition: opening in the fetal heart that allows blood to flow directly from the right atrium to the left atrium, bypassing the fetal pulmonary circuit

fossa ovalis.definition: oval-shaped depression in the interatrial septum that marks the former location of the foramen ovale

Frank-Starling mechanism.definition: relationship between ventricular stretch and contraction in which the force of heart contraction is directly proportional to the initial length of the muscle fiber

great cardiac vein.definition: vessel that follows the interventricular sulcus on the anterior surface of the heart and flows along the coronary sulcus into the coronary sinus on the posterior surface; parallels the anterior interventricular artery and drains the areas supplied by this vessel

heart block.definition: interruption in the normal conduction pathway

heart bulge.definition: prominent feature on the anterior surface of the heart, reflecting early cardiac development

heart rate (HR).definition: number of times the heart contracts (beats) per minute

heart sounds.definition: sounds heard via auscultation with a stethoscope of the closing of the atrioventricular valves (âlubâ) and semilunar valves (âdubâ)

hypertrophic cardiomyopathy.definition: pathological enlargement of the heart, generally for no known reason

inferior vena cava.definition: large systemic vein that returns blood to the heart from the inferior portion of the body

interatrial band.definition: (also, Bachmannâs bundle) group of specialized conducting cells that transmit the impulse directly from the SA node in the right atrium to the left atrium

interatrial septum.definition: cardiac septum located between the two atria; contains the fossa ovalis after birth

intercalated disc.definition: physical junction between adjacent cardiac muscle cells; consisting of desmosomes, specialized linking proteoglycans, and gap junctions that allow passage of ions between the two cells

internodal pathways.definition: specialized conductile cells within the atria that transmit the impulse from the SA node throughout the myocardial cells of the atrium and to the AV node

interventricular septum.definition: cardiac septum located between the two ventricles

isovolumic contraction.definition: (also, isovolumetric contraction) initial phase of ventricular contraction in which tension and pressure in the ventricle increase, but no blood is pumped or ejected from the heart

isovolumic ventricular relaxation phase.definition: initial phase of the ventricular diastole when pressure in the ventricles drops below pressure in the two major arteries, the pulmonary trunk, and the aorta, and blood attempts to flow back into the ventricles, producing the dicrotic notch of the ECG and closing the two semilunar valves

left atrioventricular valve.definition: (also, mitral valve or bicuspid valve) valve located between the left atrium and ventricle; consists of two flaps of tissue

marginal arteries.definition: branches of the right coronary artery that supply blood to the superficial portions of the right ventricle

mesoderm.definition: one of the three primary germ layers that differentiate early in embryonic development

mesothelium.definition: simple squamous epithelial portion of serous membranes, such as the superficial portion of the epicardium (the visceral pericardium) and the deepest portion of the pericardium (the parietal pericardium)

middle cardiac vein.definition: vessel that parallels and drains the areas supplied by the posterior interventricular artery; drains into the great cardiac vein

mitral valve.definition: (also, left atrioventricular valve or bicuspid valve) valve located between the left atrium and ventricle; consists of two flaps of tissue

moderator band.definition: band of myocardium covered by endocardium that arises from the inferior portion of the interventricular septum in the right ventricle and crosses to the anterior papillary muscle; contains conductile fibers that carry electrical signals followed by contraction of the heart

murmur.definition: unusual heart sound detected by auscultation; typically related to septal or valve defects

myocardial conducting cells.definition: specialized cells that transmit electrical impulses throughout the heart and trigger contraction by the myocardial contractile cells

myocardial contractile cells.definition: bulk of the cardiac muscle cells in the atria and ventricles that conduct impulses and contract to propel blood

myocardium.definition: thickest layer of the heart composed of cardiac muscle cells built upon a framework of primarily collagenous fibers and blood vessels that supply it and the nervous fibers that help to regulate it

negative inotropic factors.definition: factors that negatively impact or lower heart contractility

P wave.definition: component of the electrocardiogram that represents the depolarization of the atria

pacemaker.definition: cluster of specialized myocardial cells known as the SA node that initiates the sinus rhythm

papillary muscle.definition: extension of the myocardium in the ventricles to which the chordae tendineae attach

pectinate muscles.definition: muscular ridges seen on the anterior surface of the right atrium

pericardial cavity.definition: cavity surrounding the heart filled with a lubricating serous fluid that reduces friction as the heart contracts

pericardial sac.definition: (also, pericardium) membrane that separates the heart from other mediastinal structures; consists of two distinct, fused sublayers: the fibrous pericardium and the parietal pericardium

pericardium.definition: (also, pericardial sac) membrane that separates the heart from other mediastinal structures; consists of two distinct, fused sublayers: the fibrous pericardium and the parietal pericardium

positive inotropic factors.definition: factors that positively impact or increase heart contractility

posterior cardiac vein.definition: vessel that parallels and drains the areas supplied by the marginal artery branch of the circumflex artery; drains into the great cardiac vein

posterior interventricular artery.definition: (also, posterior descending artery) branch of the right coronary artery that runs along the posterior portion of the interventricular sulcus toward the apex of the heart and gives rise to branches that supply the interventricular septum and portions of both ventricles

posterior interventricular sulcus.definition: sulcus located between the left and right ventricles on the posterior surface of the heart

preload.definition: (also, end diastolic volume) amount of blood in the ventricles at the end of atrial systole just prior to ventricular contraction

prepotential depolarization.definition: (also, spontaneous depolarization) mechanism that accounts for the autorhythmic property of cardiac muscle; the membrane potential increases as sodium ions diffuse through the always-open sodium ion channels and causes the electrical potential to rise

primitive atrium.definition: portion of the primitive heart tube that eventually becomes the anterior portions of both the right and left atria, and the two auricles

primitive heart tube.definition: singular tubular structure that forms from the fusion of the two endocardial tubes

primitive ventricle.definition: portion of the primitive heart tube that eventually forms the left ventricle

pulmonary arteries.definition: left and right branches of the pulmonary trunk that carry deoxygenated blood from the heart to each of the lungs

pulmonary capillaries.definition: capillaries surrounding the alveoli of the lungs where gas exchange occurs: carbon dioxide exits the blood and oxygen enters

pulmonary circuit.definition: blood flow to and from the lungs

pulmonary trunk.definition: large arterial vessel that carries blood ejected from the right ventricle; divides into the left and right pulmonary arteries

pulmonary valve.definition: (also, pulmonary semilunar valve, the pulmonic valve, or the right semilunar valve) valve at the base of the pulmonary trunk that prevents backflow of blood into the right ventricle; consists of three flaps

pulmonary veins.definition: veins that carry highly oxygenated blood into the left atrium, which pumps the blood into the left ventricle, which in turn pumps oxygenated blood into the aorta and to the many branches of the systemic circuit

Purkinje fibers.definition: specialized myocardial conduction fibers that arise from the bundle branches and spread the impulse to the myocardial contraction fibers of the ventricles

QRS complex.definition: component of the electrocardiogram that represents the depolarization of the ventricles and includes, as a component, the repolarization of the atria

right atrioventricular valve.definition: (also, tricuspid valve) valve located between the right atrium and ventricle; consists of three flaps of tissue

semilunar valves.definition: valves located at the base of the pulmonary trunk and at the base of the aorta

septum.definition: (plural = septa) walls or partitions that divide the heart into chambers

septum primum.definition: flap of tissue in the fetus that covers the foramen ovale within a few seconds after birth

sinoatrial (SA) node.definition: known as the pacemaker, a specialized clump of myocardial conducting cells located in the superior portion of the right atrium that has the highest inherent rate of depolarization that then spreads throughout the heart

sinus rhythm.definition: normal contractile pattern of the heart

sinus venosus.definition: develops into the posterior portion of the right atrium, the SA node, and the coronary sinus

small cardiac vein.definition: parallels the right coronary artery and drains blood from the posterior surfaces of the right atrium and ventricle; drains into the coronary sinus, middle cardiac vein, or right atrium

spontaneous depolarization.definition: (also, prepotential depolarization) the mechanism that accounts for the autorhythmic property of cardiac muscle; the membrane potential increases as sodium ions diffuse through the always-open sodium ion channels and causes the electrical potential to rise

stroke volume (SV).definition: amount of blood pumped by each ventricle per contraction; also, the difference between EDV and ESV

sulcus.definition: (plural = sulci) fat-filled groove visible on the surface of the heart; coronary vessels are also located in these areas

superior vena cava.definition: large systemic vein that returns blood to the heart from the superior portion of the body

systemic circuit.definition: blood flow to and from virtually all of the tissues of the body

systole.definition: period of time when the heart muscle is contracting

T wave.definition: component of the electrocardiogram that represents the repolarization of the ventricles

target heart rate.definition: range in which both the heart and lungs receive the maximum benefit from an aerobic workout

trabeculae carneae.definition: ridges of muscle covered by endocardium located in the ventricles

tricuspid valve.definition: term used most often in clinical settings for the right atrioventricular valve

truncus arteriosus.definition: portion of the primitive heart that will eventually divide and give rise to the ascending aorta and pulmonary trunk

valve.definition: in the cardiovascular system, a specialized structure located within the heart or vessels that ensures one-way flow of blood

ventricle.definition: one of the primary pumping chambers of the heart located in the lower portion of the heart; the left ventricle is the major pumping chamber on the lower left side of the heart that ejects blood into the systemic circuit via the aorta and receives blood from the left atrium; the right ventricle is the major pumping chamber on the lower right side of the heart that ejects blood into the pulmonary circuit via the pulmonary trunk and receives blood from the right atrium

ventricular ejection phase.definition: second phase of ventricular systole during which blood is pumped from the ventricle

abdominal aorta.definition: portion of the aorta inferior to the aortic hiatus and superior to the common iliac arteries

adrenal artery.definition: branch of the abdominal aorta; supplies blood to the adrenal (suprarenal) glands

adrenal vein.definition: drains the adrenal or suprarenal glands that are immediately superior to the kidneys; the right adrenal vein enters the inferior vena cava directly and the left adrenal vein enters the left renal vein

anaphylactic shock.definition: type of shock that follows a severe allergic reaction and results from massive vasodilation

angioblasts.definition: stem cells that give rise to blood vessels

angiogenesis.definition: development of new blood vessels from existing vessels

anterior cerebral artery.definition: arises from the internal carotid artery; supplies the frontal lobe of the cerebrum

anterior communicating artery.definition: anastomosis of the right and left internal carotid arteries; supplies blood to the brain
