anterior tibial artery.definition: branches from the popliteal artery; supplies blood to the anterior tibial region; becomes the dorsalis pedis artery

anterior tibial vein.definition: forms from the dorsal venous arch; drains the area near the tibialis anterior muscle and leads to the popliteal vein

aorta.definition: largest artery in the body, originating from the left ventricle and descending to the abdominal region where it bifurcates into the common iliac arteries at the level of the fourth lumbar vertebra; arteries originating from the aorta distribute blood to virtually all tissues of the body

aortic arch.definition: arc that connects the ascending aorta to the descending aorta; ends at the intervertebral disk between the fourth and fifth thoracic vertebrae

aortic hiatus.definition: opening in the diaphragm that allows passage of the thoracic aorta into the abdominal region where it becomes the abdominal aorta

aortic sinuses.definition: small pockets in the ascending aorta near the aortic valve that are the locations of the baroreceptors (stretch receptors) and chemoreceptors that trigger a reflex that aids in the regulation of vascular homeostasis

arterial circle.definition: (also, circle of Willis) anastomosis located at the base of the brain that ensures continual blood supply; formed from branches of the internal carotid and vertebral arteries; supplies blood to the brain

arteriole.definition: (also, resistance vessel) very small artery that leads to a capillary

arteriovenous anastomosis.definition: short vessel connecting an arteriole directly to a venule and bypassing the capillary beds

artery.definition: blood vessel that conducts blood away from the heart; may be a conducting or distributing vessel

ascending aorta.definition: initial portion of the aorta, rising from the left ventricle for a distance of approximately 5 cm

atrial reflex.definition: mechanism for maintaining vascular homeostasis involving atrial baroreceptors: if blood is returning to the right atrium more rapidly than it is being ejected from the left ventricle, the atrial receptors will stimulate the cardiovascular centers to increase sympathetic firing and increase cardiac output until the situation is reversed; the opposite is also true

axillary artery.definition: continuation of the subclavian artery as it penetrates the body wall and enters the axillary region; supplies blood to the region near the head of the humerus (humeral circumflex arteries); the majority of the vessel continues into the brachium and becomes the brachial artery

axillary vein.definition: major vein in the axillary region; drains the upper limb and becomes the subclavian vein

azygos vein.definition: originates in the lumbar region and passes through the diaphragm into the thoracic cavity on the right side of the vertebral column; drains blood from the intercostal veins, esophageal veins, bronchial veins, and other veins draining the mediastinal region; leads to the superior vena cava

basilar artery.definition: formed from the fusion of the two vertebral arteries; sends branches to the cerebellum, brain stem, and the posterior cerebral arteries; the main blood supply to the brain stem

basilic vein.definition: superficial vein of the arm that arises from the palmar venous arches, intersects with the median cubital vein, parallels the ulnar vein, and continues into the upper arm; along with the brachial vein, it leads to the axillary vein

blood colloidal osmotic pressure (BCOP).definition: pressure exerted by colloids suspended in blood within a vessel; a primary determinant is the presence of plasma proteins

blood flow.definition: movement of blood through a vessel, tissue, or organ that is usually expressed in terms of volume per unit of time

blood hydrostatic pressure.definition: force blood exerts against the walls of a blood vessel or heart chamber

blood islands.definition: masses of developing blood vessels and formed elements from mesodermal cells scattered throughout the embryonic disc

blood pressure.definition: force exerted by the blood against the wall of a vessel or heart chamber; can be described with the more generic term hydrostatic pressure

brachial artery.definition: continuation of the axillary artery in the brachium; supplies blood to much of the brachial region; gives off several smaller branches that provide blood to the posterior surface of the arm in the region of the elbow; bifurcates into the radial and ulnar arteries at the coronoid fossa

brachial vein.definition: deeper vein of the arm that forms from the radial and ulnar veins in the lower arm; leads to the axillary vein

brachiocephalic artery.definition: single vessel located on the right side of the body; the first vessel branching from the aortic arch; gives rise to the right subclavian artery and the right common carotid artery; supplies blood to the head, neck, upper limb, and wall of the thoracic region

brachiocephalic vein.definition: one of a pair of veins that form from a fusion of the external and internal jugular veins and the subclavian vein; subclavian, external and internal jugulars, vertebral, and internal thoracic veins lead to it; drains the upper thoracic region and flows into the superior vena cava

bronchial artery.definition: systemic branch from the aorta that provides oxygenated blood to the lungs in addition to the pulmonary circuit

bronchial vein.definition: drains the systemic circulation from the lungs and leads to the azygos vein

capacitance.definition: ability of a vein to distend and store blood

capillary.definition: smallest of blood vessels where physical exchange occurs between the blood and tissue cells surrounded by interstitial fluid

capillary bed.definition: network of 10â100 capillaries connecting arterioles to venules

capillary hydrostatic pressure (CHP).definition: force blood exerts against a capillary

cardiogenic shock.definition: type of shock that results from the inability of the heart to maintain cardiac output

carotid sinuses.definition: small pockets near the base of the internal carotid arteries that are the locations of the baroreceptors and chemoreceptors that trigger a reflex that aids in the regulation of vascular homeostasis

cavernous sinus.definition: enlarged vein that receives blood from most of the other cerebral veins and the eye socket, and leads to the petrosal sinus

celiac trunk.definition: (also, celiac artery) major branch of the abdominal aorta; gives rise to the left gastric artery, the splenic artery, and the common hepatic artery that forms the hepatic artery to the liver, the right gastric artery to the stomach, and the cystic artery to the gall bladder

cephalic vein.definition: superficial vessel in the upper arm; leads to the axillary vein

cerebrovascular accident (CVA).definition: blockage of blood flow to the brain; also called a stroke

circle of Willis.definition: (also, arterial circle) anastomosis located at the base of the brain that ensures continual blood supply; formed from branches of the internal carotid and vertebral arteries; supplies blood to the brain

circulatory shock.definition: also simply called shock; a life-threatening medical condition in which the circulatory system is unable to supply enough blood flow to provide adequate oxygen and other nutrients to the tissues to maintain cellular metabolism

common carotid artery.definition: right common carotid artery arises from the brachiocephalic artery, and the left common carotid arises from the aortic arch; gives rise to the external and internal carotid arteries; supplies the respective sides of the head and neck

common hepatic artery.definition: branch of the celiac trunk that forms the hepatic artery, the right gastric artery, and the cystic artery

common iliac artery.definition: branch of the aorta that leads to the internal and external iliac arteries

common iliac vein.definition: one of a pair of veins that flows into the inferior vena cava at the level of L5; the left common iliac vein drains the sacral region; divides into external and internal iliac veins near the inferior portion of the sacroiliac joint

compliance.definition: degree to which a blood vessel can stretch as opposed to being rigid

continuous capillary.definition: most common type of capillary, found in virtually all tissues except epithelia and cartilage; contains very small gaps in the endothelial lining that permit exchange

cystic artery.definition: branch of the common hepatic artery; supplies blood to the gall bladder

deep femoral artery.definition: branch of the femoral artery; gives rise to the lateral circumflex arteries

deep femoral vein.definition: drains blood from the deeper portions of the thigh and leads to the femoral vein

descending aorta.definition: portion of the aorta that continues downward past the end of the aortic arch; subdivided into the thoracic aorta and the abdominal aorta

diastolic pressure.definition: lower number recorded when measuring arterial blood pressure; represents the minimal value corresponding to the pressure that remains during ventricular relaxation

digital arteries.definition: formed from the superficial and deep palmar arches; supply blood to the digits

digital veins.definition: drain the digits and feed into the palmar arches of the hand and dorsal venous arch of the foot

dorsal arch.definition: (also, arcuate arch) formed from the anastomosis of the dorsalis pedis artery and medial and plantar arteries; branches supply the distal portions of the foot and digits

dorsal venous arch.definition: drains blood from digital veins and vessels on the superior surface of the foot

dorsalis pedis artery.definition: forms from the anterior tibial artery; branches repeatedly to supply blood to the tarsal and dorsal regions of the foot

ductus arteriosus.definition: shunt in the fetal pulmonary trunk that diverts oxygenated blood back to the aorta

ductus venosus.definition: shunt that causes oxygenated blood to bypass the fetal liver on its way to the inferior vena cava

elastic artery.definition: (also, conducting artery) artery with abundant elastic fibers located closer to the heart, which maintains the pressure gradient and conducts blood to smaller branches

esophageal artery.definition: branch of the thoracic aorta; supplies blood to the esophagus

esophageal vein.definition: drains the inferior portions of the esophagus and leads to the azygos vein

external carotid artery.definition: arises from the common carotid artery; supplies blood to numerous structures within the face, lower jaw, neck, esophagus, and larynx

external elastic membrane.definition: membrane composed of elastic fibers that separates the tunica media from the tunica externa; seen in larger arteries

external iliac artery.definition: branch of the common iliac artery that leaves the body cavity and becomes a femoral artery; supplies blood to the lower limbs

external iliac vein.definition: formed when the femoral vein passes into the body cavity; drains the legs and leads to the common iliac vein

external jugular vein.definition: one of a pair of major veins located in the superficial neck region that drains blood from the more superficial portions of the head, scalp, and cranial regions, and leads to the subclavian vein

femoral artery.definition: continuation of the external iliac artery after it passes through the body cavity; divides into several smaller branches, the lateral deep femoral artery, and the genicular artery; becomes the popliteal artery as it passes posterior to the knee

femoral circumflex vein.definition: forms a loop around the femur just inferior to the trochanters; drains blood from the areas around the head and neck of the femur; leads to the femoral vein

femoral vein.definition: drains the upper leg; receives blood from the great saphenous vein, the deep femoral vein, and the femoral circumflex vein; becomes the external iliac vein when it crosses the body wall

fenestrated capillary.definition: type of capillary with pores or fenestrations in the endothelium that allow for rapid passage of certain small materials

fibular vein.definition: drains the muscles and integument near the fibula and leads to the popliteal vein

filtration.definition: in the cardiovascular system, the movement of material from a capillary into the interstitial fluid, moving from an area of higher pressure to lower pressure

foramen ovale.definition: shunt that directly connects the right and left atria and helps to divert oxygenated blood from the fetal pulmonary circuit

genicular artery.definition: branch of the femoral artery; supplies blood to the region of the knee

gonadal artery.definition: branch of the abdominal aorta; supplies blood to the gonads or reproductive organs; also described as ovarian arteries or testicular arteries, depending upon the sex of the individual

gonadal vein.definition: generic term for a vein draining a reproductive organ; may be either an ovarian vein or a testicular vein, depending on the sex of the individual

great cerebral vein.definition: receives most of the smaller vessels from the inferior cerebral veins and leads to the straight sinus

great saphenous vein.definition: prominent surface vessel located on the medial surface of the leg and thigh; drains the superficial portions of these areas and leads to the femoral vein

hemangioblasts.definition: embryonic stem cells that appear in the mesoderm and give rise to both angioblasts and pluripotent stem cells

hemiazygos vein.definition: smaller vein complementary to the azygos vein; drains the esophageal veins from the esophagus and the left intercostal veins, and leads to the brachiocephalic vein via the superior intercostal vein

hepatic artery proper.definition: branch of the common hepatic artery; supplies systemic blood to the liver

hepatic portal system.definition: specialized circulatory pathway that carries blood from digestive organs to the liver for processing before being sent to the systemic circulation

hepatic vein.definition: drains systemic blood from the liver and flows into the inferior vena cava

hypertension.definition: chronic and persistent blood pressure measurements of 140/90 mm Hg or above

hypervolemia.definition: abnormally high levels of fluid and blood within the body

hypovolemia.definition: abnormally low levels of fluid and blood within the body

hypovolemic shock.definition: type of circulatory shock caused by excessive loss of blood volume due to hemorrhage or possibly dehydration

hypoxia.definition: lack of oxygen supply to the tissues

inferior mesenteric artery.definition: branch of the abdominal aorta; supplies blood to the distal segment of the large intestine and rectum

inferior phrenic artery.definition: branch of the abdominal aorta; supplies blood to the inferior surface of the diaphragm

inferior vena cava.definition: large systemic vein that drains blood from areas largely inferior to the diaphragm; empties into the right atrium

intercostal artery.definition: branch of the thoracic aorta; supplies blood to the muscles of the thoracic cavity and vertebral column

intercostal vein.definition: drains the muscles of the thoracic wall and leads to the azygos vein

internal carotid artery.definition: arises from the common carotid artery and begins with the carotid sinus; goes through the carotid canal of the temporal bone to the base of the brain; combines with branches of the vertebral artery forming the arterial circle; supplies blood to the brain

internal elastic membrane.definition: membrane composed of elastic fibers that separates the tunica intima from the tunica media; seen in larger arteries

internal iliac artery.definition: branch from the common iliac arteries; supplies blood to the urinary bladder, walls of the pelvis, external genitalia, and the medial portion of the femoral region; in females, also provide blood to the uterus and vagina

internal iliac vein.definition: drains the pelvic organs and integument; formed from several smaller veins in the region; leads to the common iliac vein

internal jugular vein.definition: one of a pair of major veins located in the neck region that passes through the jugular foramen and canal, flows parallel to the common carotid artery that is more or less its counterpart; primarily drains blood from the brain, receives the superficial facial vein, and empties into the subclavian vein

internal thoracic artery.definition: (also, mammary artery) arises from the subclavian artery; supplies blood to the thymus, pericardium of the heart, and the anterior chest wall

internal thoracic vein.definition: (also, internal mammary vein) drains the anterior surface of the chest wall and leads to the brachiocephalic vein

interstitial fluid colloidal osmotic pre.definition: pressure exerted by the colloids within the interstitial fluid

interstitial fluid hydrostatic pressure.definition: force exerted by the fluid in the tissue spaces

ischemia.definition: insufficient blood flow to the tissues

Korotkoff sounds.definition: noises created by turbulent blood flow through the vessels

lateral circumflex artery.definition: branch of the deep femoral artery; supplies blood to the deep muscles of the thigh and the ventral and lateral regions of the integument

lateral plantar artery.definition: arises from the bifurcation of the posterior tibial arteries; supplies blood to the lateral plantar surfaces of the foot

left gastric artery.definition: branch of the celiac trunk; supplies blood to the stomach

lumbar arteries.definition: branches of the abdominal aorta; supply blood to the lumbar region, the abdominal wall, and spinal cord

lumbar veins.definition: drain the lumbar portion of the abdominal wall and spinal cord; the superior lumbar veins drain into the azygos vein on the right or the hemiazygos vein on the left; blood from these vessels is returned to the superior vena cava rather than the inferior vena cava

lumen.definition: interior of a tubular structure such as a blood vessel or a portion of the alimentary canal through which blood, chyme, or other substances travel

maxillary vein.definition: drains blood from the maxillary region and leads to the external jugular vein

mean arterial pressure (MAP).definition: average driving force of blood to the tissues; approximated by taking diastolic pressure and adding 1/3 of pulse pressure

medial plantar artery.definition: arises from the bifurcation of the posterior tibial arteries; supplies blood to the medial plantar surfaces of the foot

median antebrachial vein.definition: vein that parallels the ulnar vein but is more medial in location; intertwines with the palmar venous arches

median cubital vein.definition: superficial vessel located in the antecubital region that links the cephalic vein to the basilic vein in the form of a v; a frequent site for a blood draw

median sacral artery.definition: continuation of the aorta into the sacrum

mediastinal artery.definition: branch of the thoracic aorta; supplies blood to the mediastinum

metarteriole.definition: short vessel arising from a terminal arteriole that branches to supply a capillary bed

middle cerebral artery.definition: another branch of the internal carotid artery; supplies blood to the temporal and parietal lobes of the cerebrum

middle sacral vein.definition: drains the sacral region and leads to the left common iliac vein

muscular artery.definition: (also, distributing artery) artery with abundant smooth muscle in the tunica media that branches to distribute blood to the arteriole network

myogenic response.definition: constriction or dilation in the walls of arterioles in response to pressures related to blood flow; reduces high blood flow or increases low blood flow to help maintain consistent flow to the capillary network

nervi vasorum.definition: small nerve fibers found in arteries and veins that trigger contraction of the smooth muscle in their walls

net filtration pressure (NFP).definition: force driving fluid out of the capillary and into the tissue spaces; equal to the difference of the capillary hydrostatic pressure and the blood colloidal osmotic pressure

neurogenic shock.definition: type of shock that occurs with cranial or high spinal injuries that damage the cardiovascular centers in the medulla oblongata or the nervous fibers originating from this region

obstructive shock.definition: type of shock that occurs when a significant portion of the vascular system is blocked

occipital sinus.definition: enlarged vein that drains the occipital region near the falx cerebelli and flows into the left and right transverse sinuses, and also into the vertebral veins

ophthalmic artery.definition: branch of the internal carotid artery; supplies blood to the eyes

ovarian artery.definition: branch of the abdominal aorta; supplies blood to the ovary, uterine (Fallopian) tube, and uterus

ovarian vein.definition: drains the ovary; the right ovarian vein leads to the inferior vena cava and the left ovarian vein leads to the left renal vein

palmar arches.definition: superficial and deep arches formed from anastomoses of the radial and ulnar arteries; supply blood to the hand and digital arteries

palmar venous arches.definition: drain the hand and digits, and feed into the radial and ulnar veins

parietal branches.definition: (also, somatic branches) group of arterial branches of the thoracic aorta; includes those that supply blood to the thoracic cavity, vertebral column, and the superior surface of the diaphragm

perfusion.definition: distribution of blood into the capillaries so the tissues can be supplied

pericardial artery.definition: branch of the thoracic aorta; supplies blood to the pericardium

petrosal sinus.definition: enlarged vein that receives blood from the cavernous sinus and flows into the internal jugular vein

phrenic vein.definition: drains the diaphragm; the right phrenic vein flows into the inferior vena cava and the left phrenic vein leads to the left renal vein

plantar arch.definition: formed from the anastomosis of the dorsalis pedis artery and medial and plantar arteries; branches supply the distal portions of the foot and digits

plantar veins.definition: drain the foot and lead to the plantar venous arch

plantar venous arch.definition: formed from the plantar veins; leads to the anterior and posterior tibial veins through anastomoses

popliteal artery.definition: continuation of the femoral artery posterior to the knee; branches into the anterior and posterior tibial arteries

popliteal vein.definition: continuation of the femoral vein behind the knee; drains the region behind the knee and forms from the fusion of the fibular and anterior and posterior tibial veins

posterior cerebral artery.definition: branch of the basilar artery that forms a portion of the posterior segment of the arterial circle; supplies blood to the posterior portion of the cerebrum and brain stem

posterior communicating artery.definition: branch of the posterior cerebral artery that forms part of the posterior portion of the arterial circle; supplies blood to the brain

posterior tibial artery.definition: branch from the popliteal artery that gives rise to the fibular or peroneal artery; supplies blood to the posterior tibial region

posterior tibial vein.definition: forms from the dorsal venous arch; drains the area near the posterior surface of the tibia and leads to the popliteal vein

precapillary sphincters.definition: circular rings of smooth muscle that surround the entrance to a capillary and regulate blood flow into that capillary

pulmonary artery.definition: one of two branches, left and right, that divides off from the pulmonary trunk and leads to smaller arterioles and eventually to the pulmonary capillaries

pulmonary circuit.definition: system of blood vessels that provide gas exchange via a network of arteries, veins, and capillaries that run from the heart, through the body, and back to the lungs

pulmonary trunk.definition: single large vessel exiting the right ventricle that divides to form the right and left pulmonary arteries

pulmonary veins.definition: two sets of paired vessels, one pair on each side, that are formed from the small venules leading away from the pulmonary capillaries that flow into the left atrium

pulse.definition: alternating expansion and recoil of an artery as blood moves through the vessel; an indicator of heart rate

pulse pressure.definition: difference between the systolic and diastolic pressures

radial artery.definition: formed at the bifurcation of the brachial artery; parallels the radius; gives off smaller branches until it reaches the carpal region where it fuses with the ulnar artery to form the superficial and deep palmar arches; supplies blood to the lower arm and carpal region

radial vein.definition: parallels the radius and radial artery; arises from the palmar venous arches and leads to the brachial vein

reabsorption.definition: in the cardiovascular system, the movement of material from the interstitial fluid into the capillaries

renal artery.definition: branch of the abdominal aorta; supplies each kidney

renal vein.definition: largest vein entering the inferior vena cava; drains the kidneys and leads to the inferior vena cava

resistance.definition: any condition or parameter that slows or counteracts the flow of blood

respiratory pump.definition: increase in the volume of the thorax during inhalation that decreases air pressure, enabling venous blood to flow into the thoracic region, then exhalation increases pressure, moving blood into the atria

right gastric artery.definition: branch of the common hepatic artery; supplies blood to the stomach

sepsis.definition: (also, septicemia) organismal-level inflammatory response to a massive infection

septic shock.definition: (also, blood poisoning) type of shock that follows a massive infection resulting in organism-wide inflammation

sigmoid sinuses.definition: enlarged veins that receive blood from the transverse sinuses; flow through the jugular foramen and into the internal jugular vein

sinusoid capillary.definition: rarest type of capillary, which has extremely large intercellular gaps in the basement membrane in addition to clefts and fenestrations; found in areas such as the bone marrow and liver where passage of large molecules occurs

skeletal muscle pump.definition: effect on increasing blood pressure within veins by compression of the vessel caused by the contraction of nearby skeletal muscle

small saphenous vein.definition: located on the lateral surface of the leg; drains blood from the superficial regions of the lower leg and foot, and leads to the popliteal vein

sphygmomanometer.definition: blood pressure cuff attached to a device that measures blood pressure

splenic artery.definition: branch of the celiac trunk; supplies blood to the spleen

straight sinus.definition: enlarged vein that drains blood from the brain; receives most of the blood from the great cerebral vein and flows into the left or right transverse sinus

subclavian artery.definition: right subclavian arises from the brachiocephalic artery, whereas the left subclavian artery arises from the aortic arch; gives rise to the internal thoracic, vertebral, and thyrocervical arteries; supplies blood to the arms, chest, shoulders, back, and central nervous system

subclavian vein.definition: located deep in the thoracic cavity; becomes the axillary vein as it enters the axillary region; drains the axillary and smaller local veins near the scapular region; leads to the brachiocephalic vein

subscapular vein.definition: drains blood from the subscapular region and leads to the axillary vein

superior mesenteric artery.definition: branch of the abdominal aorta; supplies blood to the small intestine (duodenum, jejunum, and ileum), the pancreas, and a majority of the large intestine

superior phrenic artery.definition: branch of the thoracic aorta; supplies blood to the superior surface of the diaphragm

superior sagittal sinus.definition: enlarged vein located midsagittally between the meningeal and periosteal layers of the dura mater within the falx cerebri; receives most of the blood drained from the superior surface of the cerebrum and leads to the inferior jugular vein and the vertebral vein

superior vena cava.definition: large systemic vein; drains blood from most areas superior to the diaphragm; empties into the right atrium

systolic pressure.definition: larger number recorded when measuring arterial blood pressure; represents the maximum value following ventricular contraction

temporal vein.definition: drains blood from the temporal region and leads to the external jugular vein

testicular artery.definition: branch of the abdominal aorta; will ultimately travel outside the body cavity to the testes and form one component of the spermatic cord

testicular vein.definition: drains the testes and forms part of the spermatic cord; the right testicular vein empties directly into the inferior vena cava and the left testicular vein empties into the left renal vein

thoracic aorta.definition: portion of the descending aorta superior to the aortic hiatus

thoroughfare channel.definition: continuation of the metarteriole that enables blood to bypass a capillary bed and flow directly into a venule, creating a vascular shunt

thyrocervical artery.definition: arises from the subclavian artery; supplies blood to the thyroid, the cervical region, the upper back, and shoulder

transient ischemic attack (TIA).definition: temporary loss of neurological function caused by a brief interruption in blood flow; also known as a mini-stroke

transverse sinuses.definition: pair of enlarged veins near the lambdoid suture that drain the occipital, sagittal, and straight sinuses, and leads to the sigmoid sinuses

trunk.definition: large vessel that gives rise to smaller vessels

tunica externa.definition: (also, tunica adventitia) outermost layer or tunic of a vessel (except capillaries)

tunica intima.definition: (also, tunica interna) innermost lining or tunic of a vessel

tunica media.definition: middle layer or tunic of a vessel (except capillaries)

ulnar artery.definition: formed at the bifurcation of the brachial artery; parallels the ulna; gives off smaller branches until it reaches the carpal region where it fuses with the radial artery to form the superficial and deep palmar arches; supplies blood to the lower arm and carpal region

ulnar vein.definition: parallels the ulna and ulnar artery; arises from the palmar venous arches and leads to the brachial vein

umbilical arteries.definition: pair of vessels that runs within the umbilical cord and carries fetal blood low in oxygen and high in waste to the placenta for exchange with maternal blood

umbilical vein.definition: single vessel that originates in the placenta and runs within the umbilical cord, carrying oxygen- and nutrient-rich blood to the fetal heart

vasa vasorum.definition: small blood vessels located within the walls or tunics of larger vessels that supply nourishment to and remove wastes from the cells of the vessels

vascular shock.definition: type of shock that occurs when arterioles lose their normal muscular tone and dilate dramatically

vascular shunt.definition: continuation of the metarteriole and thoroughfare channel that allows blood to bypass the capillary beds to flow directly from the arterial to the venous circulation

vascular tone.definition: contractile state of smooth muscle in a blood vessel

vascular tubes.definition: rudimentary blood vessels in a developing fetus

vasoconstriction.definition: constriction of the smooth muscle of a blood vessel, resulting in a decreased vascular diameter

vasodilation.definition: relaxation of the smooth muscle in the wall of a blood vessel, resulting in an increased vascular diameter

vasomotion.definition: irregular, pulsating flow of blood through capillaries and related structures

vein.definition: blood vessel that conducts blood toward the heart

venous reserve.definition: volume of blood contained within systemic veins in the integument, bone marrow, and liver that can be returned to the heart for circulation, if needed

venule.definition: small vessel leading from the capillaries to veins

vertebral artery.definition: arises from the subclavian artery and passes through the vertebral foramen through the foramen magnum to the brain; joins with the internal carotid artery to form the arterial circle; supplies blood to the brain and spinal cord

vertebral vein.definition: arises from the base of the brain and the cervical region of the spinal cord; passes through the intervertebral foramina in the cervical vertebrae; drains smaller veins from the cranium, spinal cord, and vertebrae, and leads to the brachiocephalic vein; counterpart of the vertebral artery

visceral branches.definition: branches of the descending aorta that supply blood to the viscera

active immunity.definition: immunity developed from an individualâs own immune system

acute inflammation.definition: inflammation occurring for a limited time period; rapidly developing

adaptive immune response.definition: relatively slow but very specific and effective immune response controlled by lymphocytes

antibody.definition: antigen-specific protein secreted by plasma cells; immunoglobulin

antigen.definition: molecule recognized by the receptors of B and T lymphocytes

antigen presentation.definition: binding of processed antigen to the protein-binding cleft of a major histocompatibility complex molecule

antigen processing.definition: internalization and digestion of antigen in an antigen-presenting cell

antigen receptor.definition: two-chain receptor by which lymphocytes recognize antigen

antigenic determinant.definition: (also, epitope) one of the chemical groups recognized by a single type of lymphocyte antigen receptor

B cells.definition: lymphocytes that act by differentiating into an antibody-secreting plasma cell

barrier defenses.definition: antipathogen defenses deriving from a barrier that physically prevents pathogens from entering the body to establish an infection

bone marrow.definition: tissue found inside bones; the site of all blood cell differentiation and maturation of B lymphocytes

bronchus-associated lymphoid tissue (BAL.definition: lymphoid nodule associated with the respiratory tract

central tolerance.definition: B cell tolerance induced in immature B cells of the bone marrow

chronic inflammation.definition: inflammation occurring for long periods of time

chyle.definition: lipid-rich lymph inside the lymphatic capillaries of the small intestine

cisterna chyli.definition: bag-like vessel that forms the beginning of the thoracic duct

class switching.definition: ability of B cells to change the class of antibody they produce without altering the specificity for antigen

clonal anergy.definition: process whereby B cells that react to soluble antigens in bone marrow are made nonfunctional

clonal deletion.definition: removal of self-reactive B cells by inducing apoptosis

clonal expansion.definition: growth of a clone of selected lymphocytes

clonal selection.definition: stimulating growth of lymphocytes that have specific receptors

clone.definition: group of lymphocytes sharing the same antigen receptor

complement.definition: enzymatic cascade of constitutive blood proteins that have antipathogen effects, including the direct killing of bacteria

constant region domain.definition: part of a lymphocyte antigen receptor that does not vary much between different receptor types

cytotoxic T cells (Tc).definition: T lymphocytes with the ability to induce apoptosis in target cells

delayed hypersensitivity.definition: (type IV) T cell-mediated immune response against pathogens infiltrating interstitial tissues, causing cellular infiltrate

early induced immune response.definition: includes antimicrobial proteins stimulated during the first several days of an infection

effector T cells.definition: immune cells with a direct, adverse effect on a pathogen

efferent lymphatic vessels.definition: lead out of a lymph node

erythroblastosis fetalis.definition: disease of Rh factor-positive newborns in Rh-negative mothers with multiple Rh-positive children; resulting from the action of maternal antibodies against fetal blood

fas ligand.definition: molecule expressed on cytotoxic T cells and NK cells that binds to the fas molecule on a target cell and induces it do undergo apoptosis

Fc region.definition: in an antibody molecule, the site where the two termini of the heavy chains come together; many cells have receptors for this portion of the antibody, adding functionality to these molecules

germinal centers.definition: clusters of rapidly proliferating B cells found in secondary lymphoid tissues

graft-versus-host disease.definition: in bone marrow transplants; occurs when the transplanted cells mount an immune response against the recipient

granzyme.definition: apoptosis-inducing substance contained in granules of NK cells and cytotoxic T cells

heavy chain.definition: larger protein chain of an antibody

helper T cells (Th).definition: T cells that secrete cytokines to enhance other immune responses, involved in activation of both B and T cell lymphocytes

high endothelial venules.definition: vessels containing unique endothelial cells specialized to allow migration of lymphocytes from the blood to the lymph node

histamine.definition: vasoactive mediator in granules of mast cells and is the primary cause of allergies and anaphylactic shock

IgA.definition: antibody whose dimer is secreted by exocrine glands, is especially effective against digestive and respiratory pathogens, and can pass immunity to an infant through breastfeeding

IgD.definition: class of antibody whose only known function is as a receptor on naive B cells; important in B cell activation

IgE.definition: antibody that binds to mast cells and causes antigen-specific degranulation during an allergic response

IgG.definition: main blood antibody of late primary and early secondary responses; passed from carrier to unborn child via placenta

IgM.definition: antibody whose monomer is a surface receptor of naive B cells; the pentamer is the first antibody made blood plasma during primary responses

immediate hypersensitivity.definition: (type I) IgE-mediated mast cell degranulation caused by crosslinking of surface IgE by antigen

immune system.definition: series of barriers, cells, and soluble mediators that combine to response to infections of the body with pathogenic organisms

immunoglobulin.definition: protein antibody; occurs as one of five main classes

immunological memory.definition: ability of the adaptive immune response to mount a stronger and faster immune response upon re-exposure to a pathogen

inflammation.definition: basic innate immune response characterized by heat, redness, pain, and swelling

innate immune response.definition: rapid but relatively nonspecific immune response

interferons.definition: early induced proteins made in virally infected cells that cause nearby cells to make antiviral proteins

light chain.definition: small protein chain of an antibody

lymph.definition: fluid contained within the lymphatic system

lymph node.definition: one of the bean-shaped organs found associated with the lymphatic vessels

lymphatic capillaries.definition: smallest of the lymphatic vessels and the origin of lymph flow

lymphatic system.definition: network of lymphatic vessels, lymph nodes, and ducts that carries lymph from the tissues and back to the bloodstream.

lymphatic trunks.definition: large lymphatics that collect lymph from smaller lymphatic vessels and empties into the blood via lymphatic ducts

lymphocytes.definition: white blood cells characterized by a large nucleus and small rim of cytoplasm

lymphoid nodules.definition: unencapsulated patches of lymphoid tissue found throughout the body

macrophage.definition: ameboid phagocyte found in several tissues throughout the body

macrophage oxidative metabolism.definition: metabolism turned on in macrophages by T cell signals that help destroy intracellular bacteria

major histocompatibility complex (MHC).definition: gene cluster whose proteins present antigens to T cells

mast cell.definition: cell found in the skin and the lining of body cells that contains cytoplasmic granules with vasoactive mediators such as histamine

memory T cells.definition: long-lived immune cell reserved for future exposure to a pathogen

MHC class I.definition: found on most cells of the body, it binds to the CD8 molecule on T cells

MHC class II.definition: found on macrophages, dendritic cells, and B cells, it binds to CD4 molecules on T cells

MHC polygeny.definition: multiple MHC genes and their proteins found in body cells

MHC polymorphism.definition: multiple alleles for each individual MHC locus

monocyte.definition: precursor to macrophages and dendritic cells seen in the blood

mucosa-associated lymphoid tissue (MALT).definition: lymphoid nodule associated with the mucosa

na\u00c3\u00afve lymphocyte.definition: mature B or T cell that has not yet encountered antigen for the first time

natural killer cell (NK).definition: cytotoxic lymphocyte of innate immune response

negative selection.definition: selection against thymocytes in the thymus that react with self-antigen

neutralization.definition: inactivation of a virus by the binding of specific antibody

neutrophil.definition: phagocytic white blood cell recruited from the bloodstream to the site of infection via the bloodstream

opsonization.definition: enhancement of phagocytosis by the binding of antibody or antimicrobial protein

passive immunity.definition: transfer of immunity to a pathogen to an individual that lacks immunity to this pathogen usually by the injection of antibodies

pattern recognition receptor (PRR).definition: leukocyte receptor that binds to specific cell wall components of different bacterial species

perforin.definition: molecule in NK cell and cytotoxic T cell granules that form pores in the membrane of a target cell

peripheral tolerance.definition: mature B cell made tolerant by lack of T cell help

phagocytosis.definition: movement of material from the outside to the inside of the cells via vesicles made from invaginations of the plasma membrane

plasma cell.definition: differentiated B cell that is actively secreting antibody

polyclonal response.definition: response by multiple clones to a complex antigen with many determinants

positive selection.definition: selection of thymocytes within the thymus that interact with self, but not non-self, MHC molecules

primary adaptive response.definition: immune systemâs response to the first exposure to a pathogen

primary lymphoid organ.definition: site where lymphocytes mature and proliferate; red bone marrow and thymus gland

psychoneuroimmunology.definition: study of the connections between the immune, nervous, and endocrine systems

regulatory T cells (Treg).definition: (also, suppressor T cells) class of CD4 T cells that regulates other T cell responses

right lymphatic duct.definition: drains lymph fluid from the upper right side of body into the right subclavian vein

secondary adaptive response.definition: immune response observed upon re-exposure to a pathogen, which is stronger and faster than a primary response

secondary lymphoid organs.definition: sites where lymphocytes mount adaptive immune responses; examples include lymph nodes and spleen

seroconversion.definition: clearance of pathogen in the serum and the simultaneous rise of serum antibody

severe combined immunodeficiency disease.definition: genetic mutation that affects both T cell and B cell arms of the immune response

spleen.definition: secondary lymphoid organ that filters pathogens from the blood (white pulp) and removes degenerating or damaged blood cells (red pulp)

T cell.definition: lymphocyte that acts by secreting molecules that regulate the immune system or by causing the destruction of foreign cells, viruses, and cancer cells

T cell tolerance.definition: process during T cell differentiation where most T cells that recognize antigens from oneâs own body are destroyed

T cell-dependent antigen.definition: antigen that binds to B cells, which requires signals from T cells to make antibody

T cell-independent antigen.definition: binds to B cells, which do not require signals from T cells to make antibody

Th1 cells.definition: cells that secrete cytokines that enhance the activity of macrophages and other cells

Th2 cells.definition: cells that secrete cytokines that induce B cells to differentiate into antibody-secreting plasma cells

thoracic duct.definition: large duct that drains lymph from the lower limbs, left thorax, left upper limb, and the left side of the head

thymocyte.definition: immature T cell found in the thymus

thymus.definition: primary lymphoid organ; where T lymphocytes proliferate and mature

tissue typing.definition: typing of MHC molecules between a recipient and donor for use in a potential transplantation procedure

tonsils.definition: lymphoid nodules associated with the nasopharynx

type I hypersensitivity.definition: immediate response mediated by mast cell degranulation caused by the crosslinking of the antigen-specific IgE molecules on the mast cell surface

type II hypersensitivity.definition: cell damage caused by the binding of antibody and the activation of complement, usually against red blood cells

type III hypersensitivity.definition: damage to tissues caused by the deposition of antibody-antigen (immune) complexes followed by the activation of complement

variable region domain.definition: part of a lymphocyte antigen receptor that varies considerably between different receptor types

acclimatization.definition: process of adjustment that the respiratory system makes due to chronic exposure to high altitudes

acute mountain sickness (AMS).definition: condition that occurs a result of acute exposure to high altitude due to a low partial pressure of oxygen

ala.definition: (plural = alae) small, flaring structure of a nostril that forms the lateral side of the nares

alar cartilage.definition: cartilage that supports the apex of the nose and helps shape the nares; it is connected to the septal cartilage and connective tissue of the alae

alveolar dead space.definition: air space within alveoli that are unable to participate in gas exchange

alveolar duct.definition: small tube that leads from the terminal bronchiole to the respiratory bronchiole and is the point of attachment for alveoli

alveolar macrophage.definition: immune system cell of the alveolus that removes debris and pathogens

alveolar pore.definition: opening that allows airflow between neighboring alveoli

alveolus.definition: small, grape-like sac that performs gas exchange in the lungs

anatomical dead space.definition: air space present in the airway that never reaches the alveoli and therefore never participates in gas exchange

apneustic center.definition: network of neurons within the pons that stimulate the neurons in the dorsal respiratory group; controls the depth of inspiration

atmospheric pressure.definition: amount of force that is exerted by gases in the air surrounding any given surface

Bohr effect.definition: relationship between blood pH and oxygen dissociation from hemoglobin

Boyle\u00e2\u0080\u0099s law.definition: relationship between volume and pressure as described by the formula:P1V1=P2V2

bridge.definition: portion of the external nose that lies in the area of the nasal bones

bronchial bud.definition: structure in the developing embryo that forms when the laryngotracheal bud extends and branches to form two bulbous structures

bronchial tree.definition: collective name for the multiple branches of the bronchi and bronchioles of the respiratory system

bronchiole.definition: branch of bronchi that are 1 mm or less in diameter and terminate at alveolar sacs

bronchoconstriction.definition: decrease in the size of the bronchiole due to contraction of the muscular wall

bronchodilation.definition: increase in the size of the bronchiole due to relaxation of the muscular wall

bronchus.definition: tube connected to the trachea that branches into many subsidiaries and provides a passageway for air to enter and leave the lungs

carbaminohemoglobin.definition: bound form of hemoglobin and carbon dioxide

carbonic anhydrase (CA).definition: enzyme that catalyzes the reaction that causes carbon dioxide and water to form carbonic acid

cardiac notch.definition: indentation on the surface of the left lung that allows space for the heart

central chemoreceptor.definition: one of the specialized receptors that are located in the brain that sense changes in hydrogen ion, oxygen, or carbon dioxide concentrations in the brain

chloride shift.definition: facilitated diffusion that exchanges bicarbonate (HCO3â) with chloride (Clâ) ions

conducting zone.definition: region of the respiratory system that includes the organs and structures that provide passageways for air and are not directly involved in gas exchange

cricoid cartilage.definition: portion of the larynx composed of a ring of cartilage with a wide posterior region and a thinner anterior region; attached to the esophagus

Dalton\u00e2\u0080\u0099s law.definition: statement of the principle that a specific gas type in a mixture exerts its own pressure, as if that specific gas type was not part of a mixture of gases

dorsal respiratory group (DRG).definition: region of the medulla oblongata that stimulates the contraction of the diaphragm and intercostal muscles to induce inspiration

dorsum nasi.definition: intermediate portion of the external nose that connects the bridge to the apex and is supported by the nasal bone

epiglottis.definition: leaf-shaped piece of elastic cartilage that is a portion of the larynx that swings to close the trachea during swallowing

expiration.definition: (also, exhalation) process that causes the air to leave the lungs

expiratory reserve volume (ERV).definition: amount of air that can be forcefully exhaled after a normal tidal exhalation

external nose.definition: region of the nose that is easily visible to others

external respiration.definition: gas exchange that occurs in the alveoli

fauces.definition: portion of the posterior oral cavity that connects the oral cavity to the oropharynx

fibroelastic membrane.definition: specialized membrane that connects the ends of the C-shape cartilage in the trachea; contains smooth muscle fibers

forced breathing.definition: (also, hyperpnea) mode of breathing that occurs during exercise or by active thought that requires muscle contraction for both inspiration and expiration

foregut.definition: endoderm of the embryo towards the head region

functional residual capacity (FRC).definition: sum of ERV and RV, which is the amount of air that remains in the lungs after a tidal expiration

glottis.definition: opening between the vocal folds through which air passes when producing speech

Haldane effect.definition: relationship between the partial pressure of oxygen and the affinity of hemoglobin for carbon dioxide

Henry\u00e2\u0080\u0099s law.definition: statement of the principle that the concentration of gas in a liquid is directly proportional to the solubility and partial pressure of that gas

hilum.definition: concave structure on the mediastinal surface of the lungs where blood vessels, lymphatic vessels, nerves, and a bronchus enter the lung

hyperpnea.definition: increased rate and depth of ventilation due to an increase in oxygen demand that does not significantly alter blood oxygen or carbon dioxide levels

hyperventilation.definition: increased ventilation rate that leads to abnormally low blood carbon dioxide levels and high (alkaline) blood pH

inspiration.definition: (also, inhalation) process that causes air to enter the lungs

inspiratory capacity (IC).definition: sum of the TV and IRV, which is the amount of air that can maximally be inhaled past a tidal expiration

inspiratory reserve volume (IRV).definition: amount of air that enters the lungs due to deep inhalation past the tidal volume

internal respiration.definition: gas exchange that occurs at the level of body tissues

intra-alveolar pressure.definition: (intrapulmonary pressure) pressure of the air within the alveoli

intrapleural pressure.definition: pressure of the air within the pleural cavity

laryngeal prominence.definition: region where the two lamine of the thyroid cartilage join, forming a protrusion known as âAdamâs appleâ

laryngopharynx.definition: portion of the pharynx bordered by the oropharynx superiorly and esophagus and trachea inferiorly; serves as a route for both air and food

laryngotracheal.definition: bud forms from the lung bud, has a tracheal end and bulbous bronchial buds at the distal end

larynx.definition: cartilaginous structure that produces the voice, prevents food and beverages from entering the trachea, and regulates the volume of air that enters and leaves the lungs

lingual tonsil.definition: lymphoid tissue located at the base of the tongue

lung.definition: organ of the respiratory system that performs gas exchange

lung bud.definition: median dome that forms from the endoderm of the foregut

meatus.definition: one of three recesses (superior, middle, and inferior) in the nasal cavity attached to the conchae that increase the surface area of the nasal cavity

nasal bone.definition: bone of the skull that lies under the root and bridge of the nose and is connected to the frontal and maxillary bones

nasal septum.definition: wall composed of bone and cartilage that separates the left and right nasal cavities

nasopharynx.definition: portion of the pharynx flanked by the conchae and oropharynx that serves as an airway

olfactory pit.definition: invaginated ectodermal tissue in the anterior portion of the head region of an embryo that will form the nasal cavity

oropharynx.definition: portion of the pharynx flanked by the nasopharynx, oral cavity, and laryngopharynx that is a passageway for both air and food

oxygen\u00e2\u0080\u0093hemoglobin disso.definition: graph that describes the relationship of partial pressure to the binding and disassociation of oxygen to and from heme

oxyhemoglobin.definition: (HbâO2) bound form of hemoglobin and oxygen

palatine tonsil.definition: one of the paired structures composed of lymphoid tissue located anterior to the uvula at the roof of isthmus of the fauces

paranasal sinus.definition: one of the cavities within the skull that is connected to the conchae that serve to warm and humidify incoming air, produce mucus, and lighten the weight of the skull; consists of frontal, maxillary, sphenoidal, and ethmoidal sinuses

parietal pleura.definition: outermost layer of the pleura that connects to the thoracic wall, mediastinum, and diaphragm

partial pressure.definition: force exerted by each gas in a mixture of gases

peripheral chemoreceptor.definition: one of the specialized receptors located in the aortic arch and carotid arteries that sense changes in pH, carbon dioxide, or oxygen blood levels

pharyngeal tonsil.definition: structure composed of lymphoid tissue located in the nasopharynx

pharynx.definition: region of the conducting zone that forms a tube of skeletal muscle lined with respiratory epithelium; located between the nasal conchae and the esophagus and trachea

philtrum.definition: concave surface of the face that connects the apex of the nose to the top lip

pleural cavity.definition: space between the visceral and parietal pleurae

pleural fluid.definition: substance that acts as a lubricant for the visceral and parietal layers of the pleura during the movement of breathing

pneumotaxic center.definition: network of neurons within the pons that inhibit the activity of the neurons in the dorsal respiratory group; controls rate of breathing

pulmonary artery.definition: artery that arises from the pulmonary trunk and carries deoxygenated, arterial blood to the alveoli

pulmonary plexus.definition: network of autonomic nervous system fibers found near the hilum of the lung

pulmonary surfactant.definition: substance composed of phospholipids and proteins that reduces the surface tension of the alveoli; made by type II alveolar cells

pulmonary ventilation.definition: exchange of gases between the lungs and the atmosphere; breathing

quiet breathing.definition: (also, eupnea) mode of breathing that occurs at rest and does not require the cognitive thought of the individual

residual volume (RV).definition: amount of air that remains in the lungs after maximum exhalation

respiratory bronchiole.definition: specific type of bronchiole that leads to alveolar sacs

respiratory cycle.definition: one sequence of inspiration and expiration

respiratory epithelium.definition: ciliated lining of much of the conducting zone that is specialized to remove debris and pathogens, and produce mucus

respiratory membrane.definition: alveolar and capillary wall together, which form an air-blood barrier that facilitates the simple diffusion of gases

respiratory rate.definition: total number of breaths taken each minute

respiratory volume.definition: varying amounts of air within the lung at a given time

respiratory zone.definition: includes structures of the respiratory system that are directly involved in gas exchange

root.definition: region of the external nose between the eyebrows

thoracic wall compliance.definition: ability of the thoracic wall to stretch while under pressure

thyroid cartilage.definition: largest piece of cartilage that makes up the larynx and consists of two lamine

tidal volume (TV).definition: amount of air that normally enters the lungs during quiet breathing

total dead space.definition: sum of the anatomical dead space and alveolar dead space

total lung capacity (TLC).definition: total amount of air that can be held in the lungs; sum of TV, ERV, IRV, and RV

total pressure.definition: sum of all the partial pressures of a gaseous mixture

trachea.definition: tube composed of cartilaginous rings and supporting tissue that connects the lung bronchi and the larynx; provides a route for air to enter and exit the lung

trachealis muscle.definition: smooth muscle located in the fibroelastic membrane of the trachea

transpulmonary pressure.definition: pressure difference between the intrapleural and intra-alveolar pressures

true vocal cord.definition: one of the pair of folded, white membranes that have a free inner edge that oscillates as air passes through to produce sound

type I alveolar cell.definition: squamous epithelial cells that are the major cell type in the alveolar wall; highly permeable to gases

type II alveolar cell.definition: cuboidal epithelial cells that are the minor cell type in the alveolar wall; secrete pulmonary surfactant

ventilation.definition: movement of air into and out of the lungs; consists of inspiration and expiration

ventral respiratory group (VRG).definition: region of the medulla oblongata that stimulates the contraction of the accessory muscles involved in respiration to induce forced inspiration and expiration

vestibular fold.definition: part of the folded region of the glottis composed of mucous membrane; supports the epiglottis during swallowing

visceral pleura.definition: innermost layer of the pleura that is superficial to the lungs and extends into the lung fissures

vital capacity (VC).definition: sum of TV, ERV, and IRV, which is all the volumes that participate in gas exchange

absorption.definition: passage of digested products from the intestinal lumen through mucosal cells and into the bloodstream or lacteals

accessory digestive organ.definition: includes teeth, tongue, salivary glands, gallbladder, liver, and pancreas

accessory duct.definition: (also, duct of Santorini) duct that runs from the pancreas into the duodenum

acinus.definition: cluster of glandular epithelial cells in the pancreas that secretes pancreatic juice in the pancreas

alimentary canal.definition: continuous muscular digestive tube that extends from the mouth to the anus

aminopeptidase.definition: brush border enzyme that acts on proteins

anal canal.definition: final segment of the large intestine

anal column.definition: long fold of mucosa in the anal canal

appendix.definition: (vermiform appendix) coiled tube attached to the cecum

bile.definition: alkaline solution produced by the liver and important for the emulsification of lipids

bile canaliculus.definition: small duct between hepatocytes that collects bile

bilirubin.definition: main bile pigment, which is responsible for the brown color of feces

brush border.definition: fuzzy appearance of the small intestinal mucosa created by microvilli

cardia.definition: (also, cardiac region) part of the stomach surrounding the cardiac orifice (esophageal hiatus)

cecum.definition: pouch forming the beginning of the large intestine

cementum.definition: bone-like tissue covering the root of a tooth

central vein.definition: vein that receives blood from hepatic sinusoids

cephalic phase.definition: (also, reflex phase) initial phase of gastric secretion that occurs before food enters the stomach

chief cell.definition: gastric gland cell that secretes pepsinogen

chylomicron.definition: large lipid-transport compound made up of triglycerides, phospholipids, cholesterol, and proteins

chyme.definition: soupy liquid created when food is mixed with digestive juices

circular fold.definition: (also, plica circulare) deep fold in the mucosa and submucosa of the small intestine

colon.definition: part of the large intestine between the cecum and the rectum

common bile duct.definition: structure formed by the union of the common hepatic duct and the gallbladderâs cystic duct

common hepatic duct.definition: duct formed by the merger of the two hepatic ducts

crown.definition: portion of tooth visible superior to the gum line

cuspid.definition: (also, canine) pointed tooth used for tearing and shredding food

cystic duct.definition: duct through which bile drains and enters the gallbladder

defecation.definition: elimination of undigested substances from the body in the form of feces

dentin.definition: bone-like tissue immediately deep to the enamel of the crown or cementum of the root of a tooth

descending colon.definition: part of the colon between the transverse colon and the sigmoid colon

dipeptidase.definition: brush border enzyme that acts on proteins

duodenal gland.definition: (also, Brunnerâs gland) mucous-secreting gland in the duodenal submucosa

duodenum.definition: first part of the small intestine, which starts at the pyloric sphincter and ends at the jejunum

enamel.definition: covering of the dentin of the crown of a tooth

enteroendocrine cell.definition: gastric gland cell that releases hormones

enterohepatic circulation.definition: recycling mechanism that conserves bile salts

enteropeptidase.definition: intestinal brush-border enzyme that activates trypsinogen to trypsin

epiploic appendage.definition: small sac of fat-filled visceral peritoneum attached to teniae coli

esophagus.definition: muscular tube that runs from the pharynx to the stomach

external anal sphincter.definition: voluntary skeletal muscle sphincter in the anal canal

fauces.definition: opening between the oral cavity and the oropharynx

fundus.definition: dome-shaped region of the stomach above and to the left of the cardia

gallbladder.definition: accessory digestive organ that stores and concentrates bile

gastric emptying.definition: process by which mixing waves gradually cause the release of chyme into the duodenum

gastric gland.definition: gland in the stomach mucosal epithelium that produces gastric juice

gastric phase.definition: phase of gastric secretion that begins when food enters the stomach

gastric pit.definition: narrow channel formed by the epithelial lining of the stomach mucosa

gastrin.definition: peptide hormone that stimulates secretion of hydrochloric acid and gut motility

gastrocolic reflex.definition: propulsive movement in the colon activated by the presence of food in the stomach

gastroileal reflex.definition: long reflex that increases the strength of segmentation in the ileum

haustral contraction.definition: slow segmentation in the large intestine

haustrum.definition: small pouch in the colon created by tonic contractions of teniae coli

hepatic artery.definition: artery that supplies oxygenated blood to the liver

hepatic lobule.definition: hexagonal-shaped structure composed of hepatocytes that radiate outward from a central vein

hepatic portal vein.definition: vein that supplies deoxygenated nutrient-rich blood to the liver

hepatic sinusoid.definition: blood capillaries between rows of hepatocytes that receive blood from the hepatic portal vein and the branches of the hepatic artery

hepatic vein.definition: vein that drains into the inferior vena cava

hepatocytes.definition: major functional cells of the liver

hepatopancreatic ampulla.definition: (also, ampulla of Vater) bulb-like point in the wall of the duodenum where the bile duct and main pancreatic duct unite

hepatopancreatic sphincter.definition: (also, sphincter of Oddi) sphincter regulating the flow of bile and pancreatic juice into the duodenum

hydrochloric acid (HCl).definition: digestive acid secreted by parietal cells in the stomach

ileocecal sphincter.definition: sphincter located where the small intestine joins with the large intestine

ileum.definition: end of the small intestine between the jejunum and the large intestine

incisor.definition: midline, chisel-shaped tooth used for cutting into food

ingestion.definition: taking food into the GI tract through the mouth

internal anal sphincter.definition: involuntary smooth muscle sphincter in the anal canal

intestinal gland.definition: (also, crypt of LieberkÃ¼hn) gland in the small intestinal mucosa that secretes intestinal juice

intestinal juice.definition: mixture of water and mucus that helps absorb nutrients from chyme

intestinal phase.definition: phase of gastric secretion that begins when chyme enters the intestine

intrinsic factor.definition: glycoprotein required for vitamin B12absorption in the small intestine

jejunum.definition: middle part of the small intestine between the duodenum and the ileum

labial frenulum.definition: midline mucous membrane fold that attaches the inner surface of the lips to the gums

lactase.definition: brush border enzyme that breaks down lactose into glucose and galactose

large intestine.definition: terminal portion of the alimentary canal

laryngopharynx.definition: part of the pharynx that functions in respiration and digestion

left colic flexure.definition: (also, splenic flexure) point where the transverse colon curves below the inferior end of the spleen

lingual frenulum.definition: mucous membrane fold that attaches the bottom of the tongue to the floor of the mouth

lingual lipase.definition: digestive enzyme from glands in the tongue that acts on triglycerides

lipoprotein lipase.definition: enzyme that breaks down triglycerides in chylomicrons into fatty acids and monoglycerides

liver.definition: largest gland in the body whose main digestive function is the production of bile

lower esophageal sphincter.definition: smooth muscle sphincter that regulates food movement from the esophagus to the stomach

main pancreatic duct.definition: (also, duct of Wirsung) duct through which pancreatic juice drains from the pancreas

major duodenal papilla.definition: point at which the hepatopancreatic ampulla opens into the duodenum

maltase.definition: brush border enzyme that breaks down maltose and maltotriose into two and three molecules of glucose, respectively

mass movement.definition: long, slow, peristaltic wave in the large intestine

mechanical digestion.definition: chewing, mixing, and segmentation that prepares food for chemical digestion

micelle.definition: tiny lipid-transport compound composed of bile salts and phospholipids with a fatty acid and monoacylglyceride core

microvillus.definition: small projection of the plasma membrane of the absorptive cells of the small intestinal mucosa

migrating motility complex.definition: form of peristalsis in the small intestine

mixing wave.definition: unique type of peristalsis that occurs in the stomach

molar.definition: tooth used for crushing and grinding food

motilin.definition: hormone that initiates migrating motility complexes

motility.definition: movement of food through the GI tract

mucosa.definition: innermost lining of the alimentary canal

mucosal barrier.definition: protective barrier that prevents gastric juice from destroying the stomach itself

mucous neck cell.definition: gastric gland cell that secretes a uniquely acidic mucus

muscularis.definition: muscle (skeletal or smooth) layer of the alimentary canal wall

myenteric plexus.definition: (plexus of Auerbach) major nerve supply to alimentary canal wall; controls motility

nucleosidase.definition: brush border enzyme that digests nucleotides

oral vestibule.definition: part of the mouth bounded externally by the cheeks and lips, and internally by the gums and teeth

oropharynx.definition: part of the pharynx continuous with the oral cavity that functions in respiration and digestion

palatoglossal arch.definition: muscular fold that extends from the lateral side of the soft palate to the base of the tongue

palatopharyngeal arch.definition: muscular fold that extends from the lateral side of the soft palate to the side of the pharynx

pancreas.definition: accessory digestive organ that secretes pancreatic juice

pancreatic amylase.definition: enzyme secreted by the pancreas that completes the chemical digestion of carbohydrates in the small intestine

pancreatic juice.definition: secretion of the pancreas containing digestive enzymes and bicarbonate

pancreatic lipase.definition: enzyme secreted by the pancreas that participates in lipid digestion

pancreatic nuclease.definition: enzyme secreted by the pancreas that participates in nucleic acid digestion

parietal cell.definition: gastric gland cell that secretes hydrochloric acid and intrinsic factor

parotid gland.definition: one of a pair of major salivary glands located inferior and anterior to the ears

pectinate line.definition: horizontal line that runs like a ring, perpendicular to the inferior margins of the anal sinuses

peristalsis.definition: muscular contractions and relaxations that propel food through the GI tract

phosphatase.definition: brush border enzyme that digests nucleotides

porta hepatis.definition: âgateway to the liverâ where the hepatic artery and hepatic portal vein enter the liver

portal triad.definition: bile duct, hepatic artery branch, and hepatic portal vein branch

premolar.definition: (also, bicuspid) transitional tooth used for mastication, crushing, and grinding food

propulsion.definition: voluntary process of swallowing and the involuntary process of peristalsis that moves food through the digestive tract

pulp cavity.definition: deepest portion of a tooth, containing nerve endings and blood vessels

pyloric antrum.definition: wider, more superior part of the pylorus

pyloric canal.definition: narrow, more inferior part of the pylorus

pylorus.definition: lower, funnel-shaped part of the stomach that is continuous with the duodenum

rectal valve.definition: one of three transverse folds in the rectum where feces is separated from flatus

rectum.definition: part of the large intestine between the sigmoid colon and anal canal

reticuloendothelial cell.definition: (also, Kupffer cell) phagocyte in hepatic sinusoids that filters out material from venous blood from the alimentary canal

right colic flexure.definition: (also, hepatic flexure) point, at the inferior surface of the liver, where the ascending colon turns abruptly to the left

root.definition: portion of a tooth embedded in the alveolar processes beneath the gum line

ruga.definition: fold of alimentary canal mucosa and submucosa in the empty stomach and other organs

saliva.definition: aqueous solution of proteins and ions secreted into the mouth by the salivary glands

salivary amylase.definition: digestive enzyme in saliva that acts on starch

salivary gland.definition: an exocrine gland that secretes a digestive fluid called saliva

segmentation.definition: alternating contractions and relaxations of non-adjacent segments of the intestine that move food forward and backward, breaking it apart and mixing it with digestive juices

serosa.definition: outermost layer of the alimentary canal wall present in regions within the abdominal cavity

sigmoid colon.definition: end portion of the colon, which terminates at the rectum

small intestine.definition: section of the alimentary canal where most digestion and absorption occurs

soft palate.definition: posterior region of the bottom portion of the nasal cavity that consists of skeletal muscle

stomach.definition: alimentary canal organ that contributes to chemical and mechanical digestion of food from the esophagus before releasing it, as chyme, to the small intestine

sublingual gland.definition: one of a pair of major salivary glands located beneath the tongue

submandibular gland.definition: one of a pair of major salivary glands located in the floor of the mouth

submucosa.definition: layer of dense connective tissue in the alimentary canal wall that binds the overlying mucosa to the underlying muscularis

submucosal plexus.definition: (plexus of Meissner) nerve supply that regulates activity of glands and smooth muscle

sucrase.definition: brush border enzyme that breaks down sucrose into glucose and fructose

tenia coli.definition: one of three smooth muscle bands that make up the longitudinal muscle layer of the muscularis in all of the large intestine except the terminal end

tongue.definition: accessory digestive organ of the mouth, the bulk of which is composed of skeletal muscle

transverse colon.definition: part of the colon between the ascending colon and the descending colon

upper esophageal sphincter.definition: skeletal muscle sphincter that regulates food movement from the pharynx to the esophagus

Valsalva\u00e2\u0080\u0099s maneuver.definition: voluntary contraction of the diaphragm and abdominal wall muscles and closing of the glottis, which increases intra-abdominal pressure and facilitates defecation

villus.definition: projection of the mucosa of the small intestine

voluntary phase.definition: initial phase of deglutition, in which the bolus moves from the mouth to the oropharynx

\u00ce\u00b1-dextrinase.definition: brush border enzyme that acts on Î±-dextrins

absorptive state.definition: also called the fed state; the metabolic state occurring during the first few hours after ingesting food in which the body is digesting food and absorbing the nutrients

acetyl coenzyme A (acetyl CoA).definition: starting molecule of the Krebs cycle

anabolic hormones.definition: hormones that stimulate the synthesis of new, larger molecules

anabolic reactions.definition: reactions that build smaller molecules into larger molecules

ATP synthase.definition: protein pore complex that creates ATP

basal metabolic rate (BMR).definition: amount of energy expended by the body at rest

beta (\u00ce\u00b2)-hydroxybutyrate.definition: primary ketone body produced in the body

bile salts.definition: salts that are released from the liver in response to lipid ingestion and surround the insoluble triglycerides to aid in their conversion to monoglycerides and free fatty acids

biosynthesis reactions.definition: reactions that create new molecules, also called anabolic reactions

body mass index (BMI).definition: relative amount of body weight compared to the overall height; a BMI ranging from 18â24.9 is considered normal weight, 25â29.9 is considered overweight, and greater than 30 is considered obese

calorie.definition: amount of heat it takes to raise 1 kg (1000 g) of water by 1 Â°C

catabolic hormones.definition: hormones that stimulate the breakdown of larger molecules

catabolic reactions.definition: reactions that break down larger molecules into their constituent parts

cellular respiration.definition: production of ATP from glucose oxidation via glycolysis, the Krebs cycle, and oxidative phosphorylation

cholecystokinin (CCK).definition: hormone that stimulates the release of pancreatic lipase and the contraction of the gallbladder to release bile salts

chylomicrons.definition: vesicles containing cholesterol and triglycerides that transport lipids out of the intestinal cells and into the lymphatic and circulatory systems

chymotrypsinogen.definition: proenzyme that is activated by trypsin into chymotrypsin

citric acid cycle.definition: also called the Krebs cycle or the tricarboxylic acid cycle; converts pyruvate into CO2and high-energy FADH2, NADH, and ATP molecules

conduction.definition: transfer of heat through physical contact

convection.definition: transfer of heat between the skin and air or water

electron transport chain (ETC).definition: ATP production pathway in which electrons are passed through a series of oxidation-reduction reactions that forms water and produces a proton gradient

energy-consuming phase.definition: first phase of glycolysis, in which two molecules of ATP are necessary to start the reaction

energy-yielding phase.definition: second phase of glycolysis, during which energy is produced

enterokinase.definition: enzyme located in the wall of the small intestine that activates trypsin

evaporation.definition: transfer of heat that occurs when water changes from a liquid to a gas

fatty acid oxidation.definition: breakdown of fatty acids into smaller chain fatty acids and acetyl CoA

glucokinase.definition: cellular enzyme, found in the liver, which converts glucose into glucose-6-phosphate upon uptake into the cell

gluconeogenesis.definition: process of glucose synthesis from pyruvate or other molecules

glucose-6-phosphate.definition: phosphorylated glucose produced in the first step of glycolysis

glycogen.definition: form that glucose assumes when it is stored

glycolysis.definition: series of metabolic reactions that breaks down glucose into pyruvate and produces ATP

hexokinase.definition: cellular enzyme, found in most tissues, that converts glucose into glucose-6-phosphate upon uptake into the cell

hydroxymethylglutaryl CoA (HMG CoA).definition: molecule created in the first step of the creation of ketone bodies from acetyl CoA

inactive proenzymes.definition: forms in which proteases are stored and released to prevent the inappropriate digestion of the native proteins of the stomach, pancreas, and small intestine

insulin.definition: hormone secreted by the pancreas that stimulates the uptake of glucose into the cells

ketone bodies.definition: alternative source of energy when glucose is limited, created when too much acetyl CoA is created during fatty acid oxidation

Krebs cycle.definition: also called the citric acid cycle or the tricarboxylic acid cycle, converts pyruvate into CO2and high-energy FADH2, NADH, and ATP molecules

lipogenesis.definition: synthesis of lipids that occurs in the liver or adipose tissues

lipolysis.definition: breakdown of triglycerides into glycerol and fatty acids

metabolic rate.definition: amount of energy consumed minus the amount of energy expended by the body
